para.paratext: An agreement in which an IT provider agrees to supply and install a new IT system, including some or all of the following elements: integration services, software, hardware, licence of intellectual property rights, and ongoing support and maintenance services.

Systems integration agreements are contracts for the acquisition, development and integration of the hardware and software necessary to produce (in conjunction with the customer's business data) an entire computer system.
There are several types of systems integration agreement:
Turnkey without any software development.
Turnkey with some software development.
An agreement for the assembly of components that have been purchased separately by the customer.
An agreement for the integration of components that have been purchased separately by the customer, including some software modification or development.
An agreement for the integration of new components with the customer's existing system, which usually involves some software modification or development.

Within these types, individual agreements will vary widely depending on the system, the customer's business and the use to which the system is put. An agreement for a new air traffic control system, for example, will have to deal with very different issues to those in an agreement for an upgraded payroll-account system. Indeed, there will be significant differences between agreements to upgrade the payroll-accounts system of a multinational company and those of a small, local firm.

However, several features suitable for larger deals have been incorporated as options. These include provision for country-specific amendments, extension of the benefit of software and services to affiliates and various measures to increase supplier's liability under the agreement. Some generic concepts such as affiliates, control and VAT/sales tax have also been included as alternatives to the UK-focused equivalents.
Other features of the standard document include:
Data protection.
Data security breach.
Restoration of lost or corrupted data.
Ownership of data.
Provisions relating to international technology export control.

The standard document illustrates the basic issues that need to be considered in all systems integration agreements that include some software modification or development. The development and modification of software are usually the hardest parts of the project to deal with in the agreement, and the most usual cause of disputes between suppliers and customers.

The standard document is generally drafted from the perspective of the supplier. However, both parties should regard it as being in their own interest to negotiate an agreement which is fairly balanced, as this will make the project more likely to proceed smoothly with few disputes. A party who feels that it has been forced into a bad bargain by the negotiating strength and leverage of the other party is more likely to be looking for a way out if things go wrong. There are almost always implementation problems when software development or integration is involved.
For more information on the issues that arise in the negotiation of systems integration agreements, see Practice note, Main issues in systems integration contracts.
This standard document is drafted on the following assumptions:
The supplier and the customer are private companies incorporated in England and Wales.
The supplier and the customer are limited companies, the agreement will be performed in the UK and the output from the agreement will be used in the UK.
The agreement is subject to English law.

No employees are intended to transfer as part of the systems integration project, and the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 (SI 2006/246)Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 (SI 2006/246) (TUPE) do not apply. If there is a risk that TUPE applies, then this should be considered carefully and the agreement amended to reflect the risk. see Practice note, TUPE (1): when does TUPE apply? For more information on when TUPE may apply to service provision changes, as well as pro-supplier drafting to address the risks of TUPE applying on entry, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): Transfer of employees pursuant to TUPE.
NIS 2 and DORA do not apply to the transaction contemplated by this template, see Drafting note, EU considerations.

This template does not contain specific drafting to address considerations relating to AI. For more information on issues to consider and some possible drafting solutions (provided by the Society for Computers and Law), see Practice note, Navigating liability for loss or damage caused by AI (UK), Article, SCL AI clauses and AI toolkit (UK).

These standards terms assume that the only services being provided by the supplier are limited to those services set out in Schedule 3, namely maintenance and support, training, consultancy and disaster recovery / business continuity. In particular, it is assumed that the end system will be hosted and operated locally in the UK by the customer after being provided "Ready for Service" by the supplier. If the supplier is providing additional services, for example software as a service, or system hosting, then further service terms should be considered. For more information, see Practice note, Cloud services.

Software is protected by intellectual property rights (IPRs), namely copyright, and, in some cases, patents as well (see Practice note, Legal protection of software). This means that IPR issues must potentially be considered for three kinds of software in a systems integration agreement:
Pre-existing software used without modification.
Pre-existing software which is to be modified.
New software which is to be developed for the customer.

Each party should carry out due diligence before entering into the agreement. They should find out what the IPR position is, and in particular, what licences are necessary for the project to go ahead and the effect of the existing contractual terms under the local law applicable to where the services are to be provided. The supplier should also seek to establish what it needs to provide the services, particularly in terms of licences from the customer, third-party licences and its own software.

In order to use pre-existing software, the customer needs a licence from the owner of the rights in the software (or from someone who has been granted rights to sub-license the software by the owner). Copyright is infringed by a number of acts, including the unauthorised copying of the copyright work. Since the mere act of loading software into a computer involves copying it onto its memory, a licence is required even for the most basic use of a computer program. If there is a patent, the use of software that is covered by any valid claim of that patent will also be patent infringement unless it is made under a licence. The precise scope of the licence is, however, a matter for negotiation between the parties (see clause 18).

Making a derivative work can also be an infringement of copyright and, if it comes within a claim of the patent, patent infringement. Standard software licences almost always exclude, to the extent legally possible, the right to modify the software. While UK law does give a right to decompile software in order to obtain information that is needed to make that program operate with another independent program, that only relates to copyright. In any event it would be unwise to rely on that right as it is limited and untested in the courts (see Practice note, Main issues in software licensing and maintenance contracts: Acts specifically permitted). To avoid liability for infringement, therefore, the supplier must get the rights-owner's permission for pre-existing software to be modified for use in the customer's system.

The issue of ownership of the rights in any newly developed software is usually difficult to resolve. Unless specified to the contrary in the agreement, the default statutory position is that the supplier will own these. The customer often takes the position that, having paid for the software to be developed, it wants to own the rights in it. However, software is very rarely written from scratch; it is usually constructed using existing modules which the software developer has developed in previous projects and which it will want to use again for other customers. This means that the supplier will not usually agree to transfer ownership of all rights.
There are a number of approaches to giving each party what it needs:

If the customer's main concern is that it does not want software that it has paid for to be sold to a competitor, the supplier could offer an exclusive licence to use the program as a whole, but only a non-exclusive licence to use the standard modules embedded in the program. If the supplier then wanted to re-use all or a significant part of the program at a later date, it could offer the customer a reduction in the original price or a payment for each further copy sold in return for an agreement to allow the program to be resold.
If the customer wants to be able to maintain the software itself, it could be given a copy of the source code and a licence which covers maintenance.

In the unusual case where the customer wants to commercially exploit the software itself, it could be given wide rights to sub-license. The customer should seek to have these rights free from restrictions, although the supplier should seek to exert some control over such sub-licensing, which could otherwise damage its business.
See Practice note, Main issues in systems integration contracts: Ownership of intellectual property rights.

It would be impractical for the customer to verify the supplier's claims of ownership of the software and of the right to license its use. Accordingly, the customer will want to ensure that it is contractually protected if the supplier is not, in fact, so entitled. This protection is necessary in case the IPRs in all or part of the software actually belong to someone else, and the licensor has not given the supplier the right to grant sub-licences. This may happen even where the software was written by the supplier, for example, in cases where it has transferred the IPRs in the software to a previous customer. It can also be relevant if, in writing the software, an employee of the supplier copied code from a pre-existing program belonging to a third party. In those situations, use of the software by the customer would constitute a breach of the third-party IPRs in the software and would expose the customer to the risk of an infringement action.

It is therefore usual for the supplier to provide some protection for the customer against claims that the software infringes any third-party IPRs, commonly in the form of a contractual indemnity (see clause 30). This may be subject to a capped amount and should exclude infringement caused by the customer's own activities (see clause 30.2). The customer will often contend that the supplier should remain liable for infringements arising from use of the software or hardware it supplies in conjunction with other software or hardware which it knew was required to implement and use the system, for example, the operating system or standard database software.
For more information, see Practice note, Main issues in software licensing and maintenance contracts: Intellectual property and indemnities.

There is uncertainty as to whether a contract for the provision of bespoke software is legally classified as a contract for the sale of goods or a contract for the provision of services, although the tax authorities have their own tests. In the case of systems integration agreements, the classification may depend on the ratio of the value of goods (standard software) to services (modifications, bespoke software and integration) in the contract. The draftsperson needs to keep in mind the provisions of legislation and case law relating to both types of contract, particularly in the area of warranties and limitation of liability.

Systems integration agreements typically include warranties relating to the supplier's rights to license the software (see above). The customer will usually seek warranties as to the performance of the system, so as to ensure that there are legal remedies available to it if there are serious problems with the system's performance. The supplier should not in general offer such warranties, and, if they are required as part of the negotiated agreement, they should be tied strictly to demonstrable performance standards, which should be contained in an agreed technical specification (see Drafting note, Warranties). This is not necessarily bad for the customer, as it results in standards of performance that can readily be measured, and failure to meet those standards will be much easier to prove in a dispute.
For more information, see Practice note, Main issues in systems integration contracts: Warranties.
See Drafting note, Limitation of liability.

The agreement must make clear the point at which the customer accepts the system. This is because after acceptance the customer has no general legal right to reject the system if it is defective and get its money back, and can only sue for damages. The supplier should seek to obtain a legally binding acceptance as early as possible, while the customer will try to delay the point in time at which it must accept the system until it has had time to fully test the system in normal use. Normally a compromise is reached through acceptance testing provisions (see clause 12).
For more information, see Practice note, Main issues in systems integration contracts: Acceptance and Checklist, IT contracts: establishing acceptance and go-live.

The customer may seek to recite specifically in the agreement its reliance on representations made in the supplier's response to the customer's invitation to tender. Suppliers should always resist a general recital of reliance and the most they will usually agree to is having the specific representations the customer says it relied on incorporated into the contract. If they are not so incorporated, the aim of the entire agreement clause is to exclude representations not in this agreement, so they cannot be relied on in a later dispute.
For more information, see Article, Lessons to be learned from BSkyB v EDS and Legal update, High Court holds EDS made fraudulent misrepresentation.

head.headtext: WEEE Regulations and product standards and labelling

para.paratext: Producers (manufacturers, resellers, sellers and importers) of new electrical and electronic equipment (EEE) should be aware that, under the the Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment Regulations 2013 (SI 2013/3113) they are obliged to finance the collection, treatment recovery and environmentally sound disposal of waste EEE (WEEE) by joining an approved producer compliance scheme (PCS). Larger distributors (retailers) also have take-back requirements to collect very small WEEE in their retail areas to return to the producers. Producers must also mark all new EEE in such a manner that they can be easily identified as its producer, and that the equipment can be readily identified as having been put on the market. Producers must also mark all new EEE with a crossed-out wheelie bin symbol (indicating it should not be disposed of as part of unsorted municipal waste).
For more information, see Practice note, WEEE regime: Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment.

In addition, from 1 January 2021, UK conformity assessments in respect of CE markings will no longer be valid in the EU and UK businesses selling into the EU will need to obtain new EU-issued certificates or transfer existing UK certificates to an EU-based assessor. The UK will introduce a UK Conformity Assessed (UKCA) mark for products that require third party assessment of conformity within the UK. The CE and UKCA markings will both be valid in the UK for a currently undefined period of time, after which only the UKCA mark will be accepted on UK products. After the end of the UK-EU transition period, UK manufacturers exporting products to the EU will need to appoint an importer and EU products destined for the UK market will require a UK importer. For more information, see Sector note, Brexit: the technology industry in the transition period and after: Cross-border trade.
The Bribery Act 2010 (BA 2010) came into force on 1 July 2011. It replaces the existing criminal offences of bribery, and also introduces new offences. It sets out:
The offence of bribing another person (section 1, BA 2010).
The offences relating to being bribed (section 2, BA 2010).
The offence of bribing a foreign public official (section 6, BA 2010).
The offence of failure of commercial organisations to prevent bribery (section 7, BA 2010).

Of particular concern is the section 7 corporate offence of failure to prevent bribery by an associated person. A commercial organisation (including a company or partnership) will be guilty of an offence if a person associated with it bribes another person intending to obtain or retain business for the commercial organisation, or to obtain or retain an advantage in the conduct of business for the commercial organisation (section 7, BA 2010).

Under the BA 2010, a person (A) is associated with a relevant commercial organisation (C) if A performs services for or on behalf of C (section 8, BA 2010). Although the BA 2010 specifically states that A may be C's employee, subsidiary or agent, it does not matter in what capacity A performs services for or on behalf of C. Whether or not A is a person who performs services for or on behalf of C is to be determined by reference to all the relevant circumstances, and not merely by reference to the nature of the relationship between A and C.

Under this definition, a supplier of services will be an associated person to its customer (the commercial organisation). As it is a customer who is at risk of committing the section 7 offence, a supplier should therefore be prepared for its customer raising the issue as part of its selection process and in negotiations:
A customer may ask questions about the supplier and its own anti-bribery policies as part of a due diligence exercise.

A customer may require comfort in the form of anti-bribery clauses in its agreement with the supplier. For an example, see Standard document, Simple framework services agreement (pro-customer). Practitioners acting for suppliers should review these clauses, as they reflect, broadly, typical obligations required by a customer.

Suppliers should consider creating and implementing their own anti-bribery and corruption policies (for information, see Practice note, Bribery Act 2010: anti-corruption policies). By implementing their own policies and procedures, a supplier can avoid the cost implications and practical difficulties in having to comply with numerous (and potentially significantly different) anti-bribery policies of all its customers. This approach will also provide comfort to a customer that it is dealing with a supplier that takes the BA 2010 seriously.
The supplier's own policies and procedures should be annexed to their own standard form commercial agreements which fall into scope of the section 7 offence.

If amending a customer's anti-bribery clauses to reduce their strength (for example, by making them warranties), a supplier should note that a well advised customer is very likely to reject this approach in negotiations, as it will rightly point out that it is the party who risks committing the criminal offence under section 7 of the BA 2010.

Where the arrangement includes a supply chain, so that the supplier is appointing subcontractors to perform services, a supplier will need to do appropriate anti-bribery due diligence on such subcontractors, and require the subcontractors to comply with any anti-bribery obligations imposed by a customer. For further information, see the discussion on supply chain issues in Standard clause, Anti-bribery clause (long form).
For information and all PLC materials on bribery, see Practice note, Bribery Act 2010: toolkit.

The payment mechanism provisions are set out in clause 14 and schedule 4. For alternative payment mechanism provisions, see Standard clauses, Payment mechanism: milestone and retention schedule (pro-supplier), Payment mechanism: milestone and delay payments schedule (pro-supplier) and Payment mechanism: time-based fees schedule (pro-supplier).
For more information on software-related agreements generally, see Practice notes, Main issues in software licensing and maintenance contracts and Main issues in systems integration contracts.

para.paratext: See Legal update, ECJ rules on exhaustion of rights in downloaded software and resale of licences, Article, second-hand software: the market opens up and Practice note, Competition law in copyright exploitation: Software.

Under UK competition law, a party's refusal to license materials protected by IPRs to third parties can in certain circumstances be challenged under Chapter II of the Competition Act 1998 (Competition Act), The Chapter II prohibition is based on Article 102 of Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), and prohibits abuses of dominance in a market which may have an effect on trade within the UK or any part of it.

In addition, Chapter I of the Competition Act, based on Article 101 of the TFEU, prohibits anti-competitive agreements between undertakings (that is, any natural or legal person carrying on economic activities, including companies, sole traders and trading divisions of public bodies), which have the object or effect of restricting competition within the UK and which affect trade within the UK or any part of it.
Entering into an agreement that breaches UK competition law can result in:
The agreement (or particular sections of it) being null and void.
The parties being subject to investigation and enforcement proceedings by UK competition authority, the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA).
Potential exposure to large fines and private actions for damages.

The EU competition rules (Articles 101 and 102 of the TFEU) will continue to apply, at the end of the UK-EU transition period, to agreements or conduct of UK companies that have an effect within the EU, see Practice note, Extraterritorial application of EU competition law.

At the EU level, an agreement that is caught by Article 101(1) TFEU may nevertheless escape prohibition (and therefore voidness) under Article 101(3) TFEU if it subject to either an individual or block exemption. For more information, see Practice note, Article 101 of the TFEU (restrictive agreements): Exemption under Article 101(3).

In the UK, Parallel exemptions apply to agreements which are covered by an EU Commission individual or block exemption under Article 101(3) of the TFEU, or would be covered by an EU Commission block exemption if the agreement had an appreciable effect on trade between EU member states. Agreements covered by parallel exemptions are automatically exempt from the Chapter I prohibition.

After the end of the transition period, the EU block exemptions were adopted into UK law as "retained exemptions", with their same expiry date, but domesticated to remove EU references. As a result, agreements that currently enjoy a safe harbour under one of these parallel block exemptions will continue to do so post-transition period. Going forward, companies entering into new agreements after December 2020 will also be able to benefit from the retained exemptions, provided they meet the relevant criteria. However, companies should be aware that UK courts and authorities may be able to divert from previous EU interpretation of the block exemptions, most likely where there are material differences in UK and EU legislation or markets, even if this is initially unlikely. Looking to the future, some divergence between EU and UK competition law may be expected as the application of EU and UK competition develops. The Secretary of State will have the power to vary (including to extend) or revoke the application of the retained exemptions.

In the licensing context, Commission Regulation (EU) 316/2014 on the application of Article 101(3) of the TFEU to categories of technology transfer agreements (the technology transfer block exemption regulation (TTBER)) is particularly relevant.

Under the TTBER, the EU Commission has removed the concept of a "severable improvement". All exclusive grant-backs fall outside the scope of the TTBER and will require an individual assessment under Article 101(3) of the TFEU. An exclusive grant back is defined as a grant back which prevents the licensee (which is the innovator and licensor of the improvement in this case) from exploiting the improvement (either for its own production or for licensing to third parties). However, non-exclusive grant back obligations are still covered by the TTBER. For more information, see Legal update, Commission adopts new technology transfer block exemption and guidelines.
For more information, see the following Practice notes:
Competition law in copyright exploitation.
Transactions and practices: UK Intellectual property transactions.
Transactions and practices: EU Intellectual property transactions.

head.headtext: Digital Markets, Competition and Consumers Act 2024

para.paratext: The parties should consider whether they are affected by the Digital Markets, Competition and Consumers Act 2024 (DMCCA) which received Royal Assent on 24 May 2024. The DMCCA provides a new digital markets regime and reforms competition law and consumer law. Apart from provisions relating to the foreign acquisition of newspapers and energy network mergers (which are already in force) the DMCCA will be brought into force by statutory instrument. The digital markets and competition aspects apply from 1 January 2025.

For more information see: Legal update, Digital Markets, Competition and Consumers Act 2024 published (digital markets and competition aspects) and Practice note, Digital Markets, Competition and Consumers Act 2024: consumer law reforms.

head.headtext: Supply chain issues: slavery and human trafficking

para.paratext: The Modern Slavery Act 2015 (MSA) is aimed at combating crimes of slavery and human trafficking. Section 54 of the MSA requires commercial organisations having a global turnover of Â£36 million or more to publish an annual slavery and human trafficking statement each financial year. The statement must disclose what steps the organisation has taken to ensure that human trafficking is not taking place in any of its supply chains or its business; or state that it has taken no such steps. Including anti-slavery and trafficking obligations in its contracts (through business policies or otherwise) is one of the steps an organisation can take.

The supplier should note that the customer may want to include wording in its supply agreements that have a connection with a supply chain to prohibit the use of forced or trafficked labour. For example, by stating that the supplier will comply with the customer's policy on slavery (and possibly its other business policies too such as anti-bribery and corruption and data protection and security). But depending on the bargaining strengths of the parties, the supplier may require the customer to comply with the supplier's business policies for reputational reasons, for example. The outcome of such negotiations would ultimately depend on the parties and how keen each of them wants to do the transaction.
For further information on the MSA including links to example clauses, see Modern Slavery Act 2015 toolkit.

Where personal data will be processed under this agreement, the parties will need to consider the impact of any applicable data protection legislation and, where appropriate, suitable data protection clauses will need to be inserted at clause 27 or, alternatively, as part of a data protection schedule to be annexed to this agreement.

The clauses which are appropriate to include, in each case, will depend upon the relationship of the parties, the context of the processing, and the capacity in which each party processes the personal data.
For some specimen personal data processing clauses designed for use in an IT agreement, see:
Standard clause, Personal data processing clauses for IT agreements (UK) (pro-customer version).
Standard clause, Personal data processing clauses for IT agreements (UK) (pro-supplier version).
Each set of clauses provide alternative options to cater for different processing scenarios.

For a note setting out the key issues to address when considering the impact of the UK and EU data protection legislation on rights and obligations commonly found in IT contracts, see Practice note, Data protection issues in IT contracts.

Cybersecurity obligations are becoming more prominent in IT agreements, including as statutory controls and obligations in relation to network and information system, and data security are increasing, see:
Practice note, Overview of cybersecurity.
Practice note, UK cybersecurity law.
Practice note, Cybersecurity in regulated sectors, cybersecurity guidance and standards.

For more information on conducting cybersecurity risk assessments, see Practice note, Cybersecurity risk assessments and reporting (UK) and for more information about managing cyber risk in an organisation's supply chain, see Practice note, Managing cybersecurity risk in supplier relationships (UK).

This standard document is drafted on the assumption that the supplier and the customer are limited companies incorporated in the UK and the services are intended for use in the UK. Where the services are used within the EU, it may also be necessary to consider compliance with any minimum cybersecurity requirements set out in current and planned EU regulations (in particular, Directive (EU) 2022/2555 (NIS 2) and Regulation (EU) 2022/2554 on digital operational resilience for the financial sector (DORA). For more information, see Standard document, Software as a service (SaaS) agreement pro-supplier: EU considerations.

The predominant cybersecurity legislation to consider is the Network and Information Systems Regulations 2018 (SI 2018/506) (NIS Regulations) which came into effect on 10 May 2018 pursuant to the Cybersecurity Directive ((EU) 2016/1148) (also known as the Network and Information Security or NIS Directive). They have potential impact on:
any operator of essential services (OES) in businesses that rely on IT systems in the following sectors: energy, transport, health, drinking water supply and distribution, digital infrastructure; and
relevant providers of online marketplaces, online search engines and cloud computing services (Relevant Digital Service Providers (RDSPs)).

Although the NIS Regulations do not set out prescriptive cybersecurity requirements, compliance with their terms requires appropriate and proportionate security measures to be implemented. This will depend on the cybersecurity risk which is identified. For more information, see Practice note, Cybersecurity Directive: UK implementation.

Like the UK GDPR, the NIS Regulations impose security and incident reporting requirements and provide for high penalties (up to Â£17 million in the case of the NIS Regulations), but their focus is on security of IT systems, rather than security of the personal data processed by those systems; in practice the two regimes are inextricably linked.

For a definition of an OES see Practice note, Cybersecurity Directive: UK implementation: Definition of OES, and for a definition of an RDSP see Practice note, Cybersecurity Directive: UK implementation: Definition of relevant digital service provider.

OESs and RDSPs have obligations to maintain the security of the systems on which their services rely and to report security incidents to their respective regulators (the ICO is the regulator for RDSPs and Schedule 1 of the NIS Regulations lists the regulators for OES).

If the customer is an OES or a RDSP, the supplier's system might be implicated in the customer's obligations under the NIS Regulations. During systems integration work the customer and supplier systems are likely to interface with each other, particularly during the acceptance testing phase. Each party is likely to carry out a range of tests and the supplier is likely to provide a variety of online development tools for this purpose. Test data is likely to include actual personal data at some point and this is when a security breach may have significant compliance consequences for OESs and RDSPs under the NIS Regulations, as well as under any data protection legislation. The customer will want to ensure that the supplier cooperates in the event of a security incident.

The customer may ask for a warranty in relation to the supplier's network security levels, and to ensure the supplier cooperates with any of the customer's regulatory obligations. An example of the type of clause the customer might ask for is set out in clause 22 of Standard document, Agile software development agreement (pro-customer). It may be reasonable to agree to such provisions, and in fact the supplier may have developed comprehensive processes and policies to support the services it provides. However, the supplier should in return ask for a warranty or some form of approval that the information the supplier provides is sufficient for the customer to meet its obligations under the NIS Regulations.

The National Cyber Security Centre has published guidance which includes advice on how to pass obligations up the supply chain and what considerations should be made in different circumstances. See also Legal update, NCSC guidance to assess and improve cyber security resilience within supply chains.
There may also be specific guidance issued by the regulator for the specific OES sector or, for RDSPs, the ICO.

head.headtext: Product Security and Telecommunications Infrastructure Act 2022

para.paratext: The Product Security and Telecommunications Infrastructure Act 2022 (PSTIA 2022) is framework legislation only, but implementing regulations passed during 2023 bring Part 1 of the PSTIA 2022 fully into force from 29 April 2024. Obligations for in scope products include periodic security updates, password administration and vulnerability management (see Practice notes, UK cybersecurity law: Product Security and Telecommunications Infrastructure Act 2022 and Cybersecurity requirements for consumer connectable products under Part 1 of Product Security and Telecommunications Infrastructure Act 2022 (UK)).

While in-scope products are generally limited to consumer products which can connect to the internet or other networks, and can transmit and receive digital data, with examples including smartphones, smart TVs, smart speakers, connected baby monitors and connected alarm systems, the PSTIA 2022 is also potentially relevant to software embedded in such devices, where those devices are being used for business purposes (but where identical products have also been marketed to consumers).
At the EU level, similar provisions apply to in-scope products with a digital element under the Cyber Resilience Act (see Practice note, Cyber resilience Act (EU)).

The parties will need to consider whether the obligations contained in this agreement are compatible with (and do not override) any mandatory obligations that are imposed on manufacturers, importers and distributors under this legislation.

There are often significant differences in size and bargaining power between parties to system integration agreements. There are a few very large suppliers of IT services who have considerable experience in most of the usual types of system integration projects. They tend to have standard terms which are favourable to them and refuse to make any significant changes except for very large customers, such as national governments. On the other hand, there are small specialised supplier firms who have to deal with customers who are much more powerful than them. For example, such firms with expertise in very sophisticated financial software may be negotiating with large and powerful banks and financial institutions. In practice, it is not in the long-term interest of the more powerful party to insist on a one-sided contract, as this tends to lead to disputes. Another risk of this approach is that, where the contract is obviously unfair, the courts are more likely to apply UCTA and other legal principles in favour of the weaker party.

The customer may ask for a source code escrow arrangement, particularly when software has been specially developed or modified. This is a means of ensuring that the customer will be able to continue to support the software, either itself or through a third-party maintainer, if the supplier fails to do so adequately or at all. While this situation may arise due to insolvency, the customer may insist that this is not the only trigger for release of the escrowed code, as suppliers who are in financial trouble tend to provide inadequate maintenance long before they become officially insolvent.

It is normal in systems integrations where there has been software development or modification for the supplier to agree to an escrow agreement. However, the supplier should ensure that the terms of the agreement:
Restrict access to the source code to circumstances where it is truly unwilling or unable to provide support.
Do not trigger access where there is merely a dispute over the cost of maintenance.

Where software has been specially developed or modified, the customer will probably seek to include, in the escrow deposit, supporting documentation that will help a new programmer to understand how the software operates. Where the supplier continues to provide maintenance, updates or new versions of the software, the customer is likely to request that the source code for any changes is promptly deposited with the escrow agent.
For more information, see Practice note, Main issues in software licensing and maintenance contracts: Escrow agreement and Practice note, Software escrow arrangements.
If acting for the customer, see also Drafting note, Source code and escrow relating to Standard document, Systems integration agreement (pro- customer).
The standard document covers all types of software supply, including:
Standard software owned by the supplier or third parties which is to be used without modifications.
Standard software to be modified for use by the customer.
Software specially developed for the customer.
Modifications to the standard document may be required, depending on what the supplier is providing.

For the supplier who is also going to provide maintenance of all or part of the system, a simple set of maintenance provisions is to be found in clause 21. If these provisions suffice, then clause 9.2(a) and Part A: Services should be deleted. Where more complicated terms are required (for example, where the software is critical to the customer's business and more detailed response time requirements are needed), it may be advisable to put the maintenance provisions in a separate, but annexed, contract. If the supplier is not going to provide such services under the agreement, then:
Remove clause 21.1.
Delete the definitions of Defect, Maintenance Agreement, New Release, Normal Working Hours, Support Commencement Date and Supported Software.

Except for very simple systems, the supplier is advised to produce a technical specification, which will set out the measurable deliverables and performance criteria that are necessary to achieve the business requirements. The supplier should also obtain the customer's written agreement that this technical specification meets their specified business requirements. This agreed technical specification will then act as the yardstick against which performance of the supplier's obligations is measured. If the supplier cuts corners by failing to prepare a proper technical specification, or agrees to have its performance measured against the customer's business requirements specification, it may find that, while the system is developed, it is trying to hit a vague or moving target, with ample scope for disagreement as to whether the requirements have been met. Having an accurate and detailed technical specification reduces the chance of disagreements over whether or not the supplier has met its obligations.

The technical specification is both technical and legal in nature. Accordingly, irrespective of who prepares it, it should be reviewed from a legal point of view as soon as it is feasible to do so. It is a crucial part of the agreement and its success depends on its technical accuracy and completeness.

Understanding the role of each document is important. The supplier will want the technical specification to be comprehensive and, once it has been finalised, for the business requirements specification to be deemed no longer relevant (particularly as it may be a source of argument under the dispute resolution procedure). It is good drafting practice to place all the supplier's principal obligations together in the agreement, as this makes it easier to check that everything has been addressed to the supplier's satisfaction.

The supplier should try to tie its obligations to modify and develop software (clause 8.1, clause 8.4 and clause 9.1(a)) to the requirements of the technical specification, which will normally include more precise definitions of the functions such software is to perform (and of any performance criteria) than the business requirements' specification will contain.

The obligations to provide the system and associated services are expressed simply as acts (see clause 8.1 and clause 2.1), completion of which it should be simple to demonstrate. The supplier should resist having these obligations tied to satisfactory outcomes of these acts described in general terms, which would be the preferred drafting from the customer's point of view. If the customer insists on some reference to outcomes, the supplier should agree to no more than tying the acts to the specific provisions of the specifications, with some allowance for error. For example, a supplier would want to agree an acceptable error rate for the conversion of the customer's data (as no conversion process can be guaranteed to be 100% accurate), perhaps combined with a provision for correcting mistakes that are found during a specified period.

While the ideal situation for the supplier would seem to be to have no obligations as to the standard of work carried out, in practice the courts are likely to view the absence of any such obligation as unreasonable. The standards set out in clause 8.1 do go somewhat further than the legally implied obligation of reasonable skill and expertise, but should be achievable by any competent supplier. Note that the outcome is expressed as meeting the requirements of the technical specification, rather than the business requirements specification (see Drafting note, Business Requirements Specification and Technical Specification above).

It is rare for a brand new system to be installed. The customer will almost always have an existing system which the supplier is going to either upgrade or replace. In either event, the supplier will need to have both physical and remote access to the existing system (hardware and software) and to the customer's data. This need for access (clause 25) has to be balanced against the customer's need to go on running its business while the new system is being developed. The customer must have an obligation to co-operate in carrying out the work, in particular to allow the supplier's staff reasonable access to information and the site, and to provide necessary supplies for the supplier's personnel working on the customer's site. The customer may want more control over rights of access than this clause gives, but the supplier must be careful not to end up in a situation where the project cannot be completed on time because access is not provided, or where it ends up paying its personnel overtime from its own pocket because access is only given outside normal working hours (unless this expense has been factored into the agreed price at the beginning) (clause 25). The customer may also require that the supplier accept an obligation of responsible conduct to go with the right of access (clause 23).
On the terms and conditions set out in this agreement, the Supplier agrees to:
deliver and install the Supplier Hardware and Supplier Software at the Site(s);
integrate the Supplier Hardware, Computer Hardware, Supplier Software and Customer Software to form the System;
carry out, in conjunction with the Customer, the Acceptance Tests; and
subject to clause 11.6, [use its reasonable endeavours to] provide the System Ready for Service by the Completion Date.
If requested to do so by the Customer, the Supplier shall:

[promptly enter into a software maintenance and support agreement in a form to be agreed between the parties OR provide maintenance and support in accordance with [this agreement including Schedule 3 OR Annex G]];
[provide the training specified in the Implementation Plan at the rates provided for in that plan OR provide training in accordance with clause 22, Schedule 3 and Schedule 4];

make available to the Customer suitably qualified personnel to carry out [such tasks on a consultancy basis concerning the Work as the Customer may specify OR tasks on a consultancy basis concerning the Work in accordance with this agreement including Schedule 3 and Schedule 4];
provide the Customer with disaster resources and business continuity services in accordance with this agreement including Schedule 3 and Schedule 4.

There may be no need for pre-installation testing if the system is fairly simple and will only use standard software. In any other case, both parties have an interest in having pre-installation testing carried out. For the supplier, this allows for testing in a controlled environment and the opportunity to correct obvious errors and deal with problems before the customer sees the software. The customer also benefits, as its employees and business are not disrupted by problems with totally untested software. Clause 10.3 provides a mechanism for dealing with repeated material failure to pass the agreed pre-installation tests. The relevant periods (in square brackets in the standard document) will have to be agreed in the light of the implementation plan as a whole and the complexity of both the system and the software.

Before delivering any item of Supplier Standard Software or Third-Party Software to the Site(s), the Supplier shall carry out reasonable tests to ensure that such item is in operable condition and is capable of meeting the requirements of the Technical Specification once properly installed.
The Supplier shall carry out the Pre-Installation Tests on the Modified Software and Bespoke Software before delivery to the Site(s) in accordance with the following provisions:

no later than [30] days from the date of signing this agreement, the Customer shall deliver to the Supplier proposed user acceptance criteria and test data for the Pre-Installation Tests for each module of Modified Software and Bespoke Software. These criteria and data shall be such as are reasonably required to show that each module complies with the relevant parts of the Technical Specification. The Supplier shall provide the Customer, at the Customer's request, with assistance to prepare such user acceptance criteria and test data at the Customer's request at the Supplier's standard rates then in force. The parties shall use best endeavours to agree the Software Pre-Installation Test Plan containing the Pre-Installation Tests for each module within [ten] days from the date of delivery to the Supplier of the proposed criteria and data, and such Software Pre-Installation Test Plan shall be annexed to this agreement as Annex E;

Within a reasonable time before the Actual Software Delivery Date for each Software Module, the Supplier shall carry out the agreed Pre-Installation Tests for the appropriate Software Module. The Supplier shall give the Customer at least 24 hours' notice of the start of the Pre-Installation Tests and permit the Customer to observe all or any parts of the testing; and
if the Software Module fails to pass the Pre-Installation Tests, the Supplier shall remedy the defects and deficiencies, and the relevant test(s) shall be repeated within a reasonable time.

If the Software Module fails, in some material respect, to pass the Pre-Installation Tests within [four weeks] from the date of its second submission to the Pre-Installation Tests, then the Customer may, by written notice to the Supplier, choose at its sole discretion to specify (without prejudice to the Customer's other rights and remedies) a new date for carrying out further tests on the Software Module on the same terms and conditions as are set out in clause 10.2. If the Software Module fails such further tests, then the Customer may:
request a repeat test under this clause 10;

permit installation of the Software Module subject to such change of acceptance criteria, amendment of the Business Requirements Specification and/or reduction in the Price as, after taking into account all the relevant circumstances, is reasonable; or

if the Supplier is unable to correct material defects within a period of [six] months from the start of Pre-Installation Tests under clause 10.2(b), reject the Software Module as not being in conformity with this agreement, and terminate this agreement.

The supplier must ensure that the customer is obliged to carry out all activities related to the site where the system is to be installed in a timely manner. Where the supplier is not providing hardware, the references to supplier hardware in clause 11 should be deleted. Similarly, if the customer is not supplying any hardware or software, clause 11.5 is not required.

This clause is favourable to the supplier in that the customer's only remedy for delay is the payment of demonstrable reasonable costs. However, the payment of liquidated damages for delay in successful completion of the acceptance testing procedure is common in systems integration agreements, and the customer may insist on it, see Checklist, IT contracts: negotiating liquidated damages.

The difficulty for the customer is in determining the sum that represents a genuine pre-estimate of its loss if acceptance of the system is delayed in order to make this an enforceable liquidated damages provision rather than an unenforceable penalty. For more information on the law relating to penalty clauses, see Practice note, Interest clauses: Too high: interest may be unenforceable as a penalty.

Subject to clause 14.3, the Supplier shall [use its reasonable endeavours to] deliver each item of Supplier Hardware and each Software Module to the Site(s) on or before the applicable Hardware Delivery Date or Software Delivery Date (as applicable) for that item.

The Supplier shall supply to the Customer, within a reasonable time before any relevant Actual Hardware Deliver Date or Actual Software Delivery Date, such information and assistance as may be necessary to enable the Customer to prepare the Site(s) for the installation of the relevant item of Supplier Hardware or Supplier Software.

The [Supplier OR Customer] shall, at its own expense, prepare the Site(s) in accordance with the information provided by the Supplier in advance of each Actual Hardware Delivery Date or Actual Software Delivery Date. The [Supplier OR Customer] may request reasonable assistance from the [Customer OR Supplier] to carry out such preparation.

Subject to clause 14.3, the Supplier shall [use its reasonable endeavours to] complete installation of each item of Supplier Hardware and each Software Module at the Site(s) by the Installation Date for that item of Supplier Hardware or Software Module.

The Customer shall be responsible for ensuring that each item of Customer Hardware and Customer Software is installed and is in working order and available to the Supplier no later than the relevant date specified in the Implementation Plan.

If any delivery is delayed at the request of, or because of the acts or omissions of, the Customer, the Implementation Plan shall be amended to take account of such delay in accordance with clause 14.5. If the Supplier can demonstrate by documentary evidence that the delay has resulted in an increase in cost to the Supplier of carrying out its obligations under this agreement, the Supplier may, at its sole discretion, notify the Customer that it wishes to increase the Price by an amount not exceeding any such demonstrable cost. The Supplier may invoice the Customer for any additional monies that become payable in this way within [30] days of demonstrating the increase in costs.
Subject to clause 14.3, the Supplier shall [use its reasonable endeavours to] provide the System Ready for Service on or before the Completion Date.

If delivery of any item of Supplier Hardware or Software Module because of any act or omission of the Supplier or any third party manufacturer or the System is not Ready for Service by the Completion Date, the Supplier shall in all circumstances be liable for any reasonable costs that the Customer can demonstrate it incurred as a direct result of such delay.

In any systems integration agreement that involves development of new software or the modification of existing software, the provisions for acceptance testing of the software are critical for both the supplier and the customer (see Drafting note, Acceptance testing and Checklist, IT contracts: establishing acceptance and go-live.
The acceptance tests are usually prepared and run by the supplier, but the customer may want to do this, or at least have an involvement that extends beyond the provision of the test data.
The acceptance tests in Annex 6 are important. This document will normally have two parts:
A testing procedure, including timetable and specification of tests to be performed.
A set of performance criteria for each test.
As it is almost unknown for this document to be agreed before the contract is signed, clause 12.1 provides a mechanism for preparing and agreeing this document.

The two parties need to reach a compromise between their competing interests in agreeing the tests and the required performance. The customer will prefer to go on testing for a long time to ensure that all problems are identified and remedied before the system is accepted (and acceptance payments are made), while the supplier will prefer short and simple tests leading to early acceptance, leaving any problems to be ironed out later under the maintenance agreement.

Where various software modules comprise part of the system, acceptance testing is likely to involve acceptance testing of the individual software modules and another set of tests on the whole set of modules as installed, to ensure that they work together properly and fulfil the business requirements specification. It is possible for the individual modules each to work correctly, but for the interfacing between them to be defective or for interference to occur between individual modules.

In any software development agreement, whether it involves development of new software or modification of existing software, the provisions for acceptance testing of the software are critical for both the supplier and the customer (see Drafting note, Acceptance testing).
For more information, see Practice note, Main issues in software licensing and maintenance contracts: Installation and testing.

No later than [30] days from the date of signature of this agreement, the Customer shall deliver to the Supplier proposed user acceptance criteria and test data for the Acceptance Tests for the System. These criteria and data shall be such as are reasonably required to show that the System complies with the Technical Specification. The Supplier shall provide the Customer with reasonable assistance to prepare such user acceptance criteria and test data at the Customer's request. The parties shall use best endeavours to agree the Acceptance Tests for the System within [ten] days from the date of delivery to the Supplier of the proposed criteria and data.

It is unusual for the acceptance testing documents to be agreed before the systems integration agreement is signed. Clause 12.1 provides a timetable (which will depend on the complexity of the software and the capabilities of the parties) and a procedure for agreeing the acceptance tests.

Within [ten] days of the Actual Installation Date, the Acceptance Tests shall be carried out. The Acceptance Tests shall be started as soon as reasonably possible after installation and shall be run continuously during Normal Working Hours. The Supplier shall carry out the agreed Acceptance Tests for the System unless the Customer notifies the Supplier, not later than five days after the Actual Installation Date, that it will carry out the Acceptance Tests. The party carrying out the Acceptance Tests shall give the other party at least 24 hours' notice of the start of the Acceptance Tests and permit the other party to observe all or any part of the testing.

Clause 12.2 provides that the supplier will normally carry out the tests, with the customer having the right to observe. Sophisticated customers with their own IT capabilities should insist on running the tests themselves, but should allow the supplier to be involved, as excluding the supplier from the testing process is likely to result in disputes if the customer alone decides the test criteria have not been met.

If the System fails to pass the Acceptance Tests, the Customer shall, within [NUMBER] days from the completion of the Acceptance Tests, or any part of these tests, provide a written notice to this effect, giving details of such failure(s). The Supplier shall remedy the defects and deficiencies and the relevant test(s) shall be repeated within a reasonable time.

If the System fails in some material respect to pass any repeated Acceptance Tests within [four weeks] from the date of its second submission to the Acceptance Tests, then the Customer may, by written notice to the Supplier, choose at its sole discretion:

to fix (without prejudice to the Customer's other rights and remedies) a new date for carrying out further tests on the System on the same terms and conditions. If the System fails such further tests then the Customer may request a repeat test under this clause 12; or

to accept the System subject to such change of acceptance criteria, amendment of the Technical Specification and/or reduction in the Price as, after taking into account all the relevant circumstances, is reasonable; or

if the Supplier is unable to correct material defects within a period of [three] months from the commencement of Acceptance Tests under clause 12.2, to reject the System as not being in conformity with the agreement, in which event the Customer may terminate this agreement.

Software rarely works correctly first time. A reasonable balance must be struck between the supplier's interest in completing and being paid for the software and the customer's need to have working software, which may at the worst involve scrapping seriously faulty software and starting again with a different supplier. Clauses 12.3 and 12.4 are fairly standard provisions dealing with failure to complete the agreed acceptance testing procedure successfully. The supplier should insist that the right to reject the software under clause 12.4(c) does not arise unless the defects are material (although the definition of that term itself is a possible ground for dispute) and until the supplier has been given a reasonable time to correct them.

Delay in acceptance caused by the customer is of great concern to the supplier in a fixed-price contract, or where a significant proportion of the price is payable on formal acceptance. The supplier will be less concerned if the contract is on a time-and-materials basis and has pre-agreed billing periods, although delay could still adversely affect its ability to do work for other clients. This clause is drafted to ensure that the customer does not drag its feet in carrying out any of its obligations relating to the acceptance testing process.
For more information, see Drafting note, Acceptance testing and Practice note, Main issues in software licensing and maintenance contracts: Installation and testing.
Acceptance of the System shall be deemed to have occurred on whichever is the earliest of:
the signing by the Customer of an Acceptance Certificate for the last Software Module to pass the Acceptance Tests;
the expiry of [five days] after the completion of all the Acceptance Tests, unless the Customer has given any written notice under clause 12.3;

the expiry of [ten days] after the Actual Installation Date of the final Software Module if the Acceptance Tests for that module have not started, or have not been pursued with due diligence, unless such failure results from the Supplier's failure to co-operate in the performance of the Acceptance Tests; or
the use of the System by the Customer in the normal course of the Business.

head.headtext: Implementation Plan and extension of time
Implementation Plan and extension of time

para.paratext: This important clause, which sets out the timetable for each stage of the project, will initially be prepared by the supplier as part of the tender documents. A version agreed by both parties should be in existence by the time the contract is signed and annexed to the agreement.

Delays are a major cause of disputes over software development projects, so it is important that each party carries out its obligations in a timely fashion. However, it is inevitable in all but the simplest projects that there will be unforeseen events that cause delay. The contract must contain a mechanism for controlling delay so that it does not get out of hand. This is provided by clauses 14.3 to 14.5. If the parties cannot agree on an extension of time (clause 14.5), it is essential to have a speedy way of resolving this (see clause 45). For more information, see Checklist, IT contracts: developing an implementation plan.
Both parties shall [use their reasonable endeavours to] perform their obligations under this agreement in accordance with the Implementation Plan.
The Supplier shall [use its reasonable endeavours to] complete the Work in each stage of the Implementation Plan by the date specified in the Implementation Plan, subject to clause 14.3.

The Supplier shall be given an extension of time for completion of any one or more of the stages in the Implementation Plan, or any of its other performance obligations under this agreement, if one of more of the following events occurs:
a variation to the System is made at the Customer's request under the change control procedures set out in clause 4 or clause 16;
a force majeure event occurs as described in clause 43; or
delay is caused in whole or in part by an action or omission of the Customer or its employees, agents or third party contractors.

If the Supplier is entitled to an extension of time under clause 14.3, it shall give written notice to the Customer not later than seven days after the beginning of the event. Such notice shall specify the event relied on and, in the case of a force majeure event under clause 43, shall estimate the probable extent of the delay.

The Customer Representative and the Project Manager shall use best endeavours to agree in writing, signed by both parties, what extension of time is reasonable in the circumstances. The Implementation Plan, or performance obligation, shall be deemed amended accordingly.
The standard document does not specify how the price is calculated or paid, so it could cover either a fixed-price or a time-and-materials basis for charging, or some combination of the two.

The customer needs as much predictability in the cost of the system as possible. However, the supplier will only want to give a fixed-price quotation for a simple system or where little customisation of an established system is required to meet the customer's requirements. The customer should not accept an open-ended time-and-materials charging basis unless there is little risk that the expected cost will be significantly increased by the end of the project. This means that a system of charging has to be negotiated that provides some sharing of the risk of cost increases between the parties. The degree of sharing will probably depend on the relative negotiating power of each party.

The customer should seek a provision that fee rates remain fixed for the duration of the contract, but the supplier may not be willing to agree to this if the project is expected to take more than a year to perform, particularly if inflation is significant. For longer periods, a method of increasing fee rates could be provided (similar to clause 15.5, which applies to the support charges).

Training costs can be included in the price or paid for separately. Support charges, consultancy charges and charges for business continuity and disaster recovery services are generally paid for separately. All these items should be included in Schedule 4 under the appropriate headings.

The Supplier shall submit invoices in accordance with Schedule 4. The Customer shall make payment of each invoice by the due date stated in that invoice or within 30 days of receipt of the invoice, whichever is later.

The details of how and when payments are to be made must be agreed and included in Schedule 4. The supplier will almost always want to have staged payments so as to maintain a cash flow to meet expenses. In return, the customer will probably seek to have payments tied to measurable progress in the project. This is often done by having a schedule setting out the milestones (specified events) and the amount payable on achievement of each milestone. The customer will probably seek to have these payments heavily weighted towards the final stages of the project, but the supplier should point out that it is not in the customer's interest to cause the supplier severe cash-flow problems, which in the case of a small company could put its future at risk either during the project or during any subsequent maintenance period.

Schedule 4 should state when payments on any invoice are due, and permit the supplier to charge interest on late payments. Suppliers should also reserve the right to suspend work or even terminate the agreement for a failure to pay after an extended period or repeated late payments. Failure to receive regular payments on time can cause severe cash-flow problems to a small supplier who must, in any event, continue to pay its employees or contractors regularly. The customer may seek to have a provision allowing it to withhold disputed amounts during dispute resolution. If the supplier agrees to this, there must be a provision for interest to be payable on any amount that the supplier is found to be entitled to at the end of the dispute resolution procedure.
For information on interest clauses, see the integrated drafting notes to Standard clause, Interest and Practice note, Interest clauses.

The Customer shall pay the Support Charges on the Support Commencement Date and on each anniversary of that date. The Supplier shall invoice the Customer for the Support Charges no later than 30 days before any anniversary of the Support Commencement Date at the invoicing address specified in Schedule 4.

The Price, the Support Charges and all other payments stated in Schedule 4 are exclusive of VAT. The Supplier shall provide the Customer with a valid VAT invoice. [The Customer shall pay any stamp duties or similar transfer taxes imposed on the supplies made under this agreement and shall reimburse the Supplier for any such stamp duties or similar transfer taxes paid by the Supplier.] If the Customer is required to make any deduction for or on account of tax from any payment due under this agreement (Tax Deduction):
the Customer shall account to the relevant tax authority for such Tax Deduction and shall provide evidence to the Supplier that it has so accounted.

the amount of the payment due under this Agreement shall be increased so that the Supplier receives an amount equal to the amount that would have been received by it, had the Customer not been required to make any Tax Deduction.

The Customer and the Supplier shall co-operate to minimise the amount of any Tax Deduction. If following the making of a Tax Deduction, the Supplier determines [in its sole discretion/ acting in good faith] that it (or any member of the Supplier's group) has received and retained any credit, relief or other benefit as a result of the Tax Deduction, the Supplier shall pay such amount to the Customer as the Supplier determines [in its sole discretion/ acting in good faith] would leave the Supplier in the same position as if the Customer had not been required to make any Tax Deduction.

Unless each party wishes to bear the tax risks "as they fall", there must be appropriate provisions relating to tax payments (such as value added taxes) and tax withholding requirements. It may be necessary to have wording to deal with tax withholding, particularly in respect of licence fees, where that is relevant. It is always advisable to obtain expert tax advice on the structuring of payments before any agreement is entered into.

[If the Customer fails to make any payment due to the Supplier under this agreement by the due date for payment, the, without limiting the Supplier's remedies under [TERMINATION CLAUSE],] the Customer shall pay interest on the overdue amount at the rate of [4]% per annum above [FULL NAME OF BANK]'s base rate from time to time. Such interest shall accrue on a daily basis from the due date until actual payment of the overdue amount, whether before or after judgment. The Customer shall pay the interest together with the overdue amount.
See Standard clause, Interest and Practice note, Interest clauses.

The Supplier may increase the annual charge at any [time OR anniversary of the Support Commencement Date after the [first OR second] such anniversary by giving the Customer at least [three months'] notice before such anniversary].

This clause provides that fee rates remain fixed for the duration of the contract (as is often requested by the customer). The supplier should only agree to a provision if the project is expected to take less than a year to perform. For longer periods, a method of increasing fee rates should be provided for. The customer may seek to limit its exposure with a condition that these increases should only happen on contract anniversaries and be limited to the average rate of inflation during the preceding 12 months, as measured by an official index.

All invoices issued by the Supplier under or in connection with this agreement shall be accompanied by a sufficiently detailed breakdown of the matters being invoiced (including [details of time taken to perform services per individual and] any additional costs under clause 15.7).
Reasonable out-of-pocket expenses may be charged by the Supplier on production of reasonable evidence of expenditure to the Customer.

Expenses must also be dealt with. Where, in addition to the contract price or its normal fees, the supplier is entitled to charge expenses such as travel costs for its personnel visiting the customer's premises, standards of travel and accommodation should be agreed in writing in advance.

For the duration of this agreement, and for a period of [seven] years from termination or expiry of this agreement, the Supplier shall maintain full and accurate records, in a form to be approved in writing by the Customer, of all charges, prices, costs and expenses associated with and invoiced in respect of the System and the Services.

Record keeping by the supplier is important to help verify invoices and deal with disputes over amounts payable and is in the interests of both parties. The customer will typically have the right to inspect these records (clause 15.9) and on reasonable notice (clause 15.10). The supplier should insist that exercise of this right be limited to reasonable intervals, for example, annually (clause 15.10).

At the Customer's request and its expense, the Supplier shall [grant access OR produce] to the Customer or its designated auditors [to the premises,] records and accounts of the Supplier [and its] [Affiliates] [and] [subcontractors] relevant to the System or the Support Services[, including its [and their] data processing facilities, and to such of its and their supporting documentation and explanations from Support Staff as is reasonable to ascertain compliance with this agreement].

Suppliers should ensure that the scope of its obligation under any audit clause is clearly defined. See (Transport for Greater Manchester v Thales Transport & Security Ltd [2012] EWHC 3717 (TCC)) (reported in Legal update, High Court considers what information must be disclosed under an audit clause), where the High Court has considered what type of information and documents must be disclosed under an audit clause in an agreement to supply services, and in what circumstances it is permissible to withhold such information.

The audit provisions under this agreement should be reviewed to ensure they reflect any audit obligations which are contained in any applicable data protection legislation, see Standard clauses, Personal data processing clauses for IT agreements (UK) (pro-customer version): Drafting note: Records and audits and Personal data processing clauses for IT agreements (UK) (pro-supplier version): Drafting note: Records and audits.

Such access shall be granted no more than once during any Contract Year during Normal Business Hours and will be subject to reasonable prior notice from the Supplier[, except to the extent that such access is required by the Customer's regulators outside of these parameters].

If, on such examination, the Customer determines that any charges, prices, costs or expenses exceed or fall short of the amounts properly chargeable to, or recoverable from, the Customer, an appropriate adjustment shall be effected between the parties promptly.

If the Supplier visits the Site(s) at the Customer's request to investigate a failure of the System, which proves in the Supplier's reasonable opinion not to have been caused by a Defect, the Supplier may charge the Customer for the time spent on such visit on a time-and-materials basis at its standard rates then in force.

It is vital to the success of any systems integration project that changes are managed in a controlled manner. This is particularly true of changes to software, which can have knock-on effects such as delaying completion of the system and increasing costs.

The key elements for pricing are certainty and flexibility, both in terms of providing performance incentives, and also to provide some means of control over pricing. This is necessary in view of the potential dynamism of the services and potential changes to the service requirements.

However, changes made to the system during implementation can lead to delays and/or increases in cost. One of the difficulties of system integration projects is that the customer can rarely define exactly what it wants before any system integration work begins. During development it is common to find that an alternative would work better, or for the users in the customer's organisation to discover that new software can add functionality, which they want but could not achieve with the old system. It follows that procedures to vary what is to be provided are essential in any system integration agreement.

Unless this change process is carefully controlled, the changes can cause serious delay and price escalation. Allowing uncontrolled variation is a proven recipe for disaster and dispute, particularly when the supplier's personnel are working closely with the customer's employees and therefore want to be helpful and provide whatever is asked for. Variations almost always add to the cost of the project and the time needed for completion. If it is a fixed-price contract, the supplier suffers, and if it is on a time-and-materials basis, the customer finds the system is more expensive than expected. In addition, both parties are affected by the extra time needed. Both parties, therefore, have an interest in controlling the variations that are made and the process by which they are agreed and incorporated in the main contract.

This clause provides a mechanism for controlling changes. However, in collaboration with the supplier, the customer must manage the contract carefully to ensure that this mechanism is always used. System engineers and programmers like solving problems and tend to ignore the official change control procedure unless they are properly managed.

In more complex systems where the supplier may not be able to accurately determine everything required for the system at the outset, the mutual form of clause 16.1 (using "either party" and " the other party" in place of " the customer" and " the supplier") allowing for change requests by the supplier should be used.
The Customer may, by giving written notice to the Supplier at any time during the term of this agreement, request a change to the System.

Within [seven] working days of receipt of such notice, the Supplier shall, at its standard rates then in force, prepare for the Customer a written [quote for] [If the changes are to be at a fixed price] OR estimate of] [If the changes are to be calculated on a time and materials basis] any increase or decrease in the Price, and of any effect that the requested change would have on the Implementation Plan.

Clause 16.2 provides the mechanism for determining the effects of any requested variation. As drafted it favours the supplier, in that the customer bears the cost of determining the effect of the requested variation. The time limit should be short but reasonable. What is reasonable may depend on the significance of the requested variation.

Within [14] working days of receipt of the written [quote OR estimate] referred to in clause 16.2, the Customer shall inform the Supplier in writing of whether or not the Customer wishes the requested change to be made. If the change is required, the Supplier shall not make the requested change until the parties have agreed and signed a written agreement specifying, in particular, any changes to the Implementation Plan and Price.

Agreed variations to the agreement must be recorded in a written document (defined as a Change Agreement in clause 1 by reference to clause 16.3). There is an inherent conflict between certainty and progress on the project. From the lawyer's point of view, no work should proceed on a variation until a formal change agreement has been agreed and signed, therefore giving legal certainty as to the scope of the contract. Unfortunately this can take time, and meanwhile the parties will want to press on with work on the project. If work is to commence before the change agreement is agreed and signed, there has to be some mechanism for resolving disputes over the change agreement and dealing with a situation where the parties cannot reach an agreement, but work has been done on implementing the variation.
