The Supplier shall in its sole discretion offer to the Customer, and the Customer may at any time before the Actual Software Delivery Date choose to obtain from the Supplier, any item of software in substitution for any corresponding item of the System where the substitute item contains new technology or has better performance characteristics than such System. As part of the offer, the Supplier shall notify the Customer of any change in the Price which would result from such substitution. If the Customer chooses to obtain any such substitute item, the Supplier shall only be obliged to provide it once the parties agreed and executed a Change Agreement in accordance with clause 16.3.

This clause is drafted in favour of the supplier, in that all rights in the software remain with the supplier. The customer is likely to object to this, at least with regard to software that has been written or modified specifically for it. The supplier should, if possible, resist agreeing to transfer ownership of these rights. There are a number of compromises that can be offered.

The supplier's starting position should be that it retains ownership in all software originating from the supplier, including modified and customised software, which includes the right to license this software to other customers. The customer may object to this, especially with respect to the customised software for which it has paid the development costs. The supplier should strive to retain ownership although it may, as a compromise, agree not to license third parties to use the customised software or those particular modifications of the standard software that have been tailor-made for the customer. However, it would be prudent to limit this restriction to a specified period to minimise the risk of breaching UK or EU competition law, see Drafting note, Competition issues.
For more information, see Practice note, Main issues in systems integration contracts: Ownership of intellectual property rights.
The Intellectual Property Rights in the System are, and shall remain, the property of the Supplier or their appropriate third party rights owners(s).

The Supplier reserves the right to grant a licence to use the System to any other party or parties and the Customer acquires no rights in or to the System other than those expressly granted by this agreement.

The Customer shall do and execute, or arrange for the doing and executing of, each necessary act, document and thing that the Supplier may consider necessary or desirable to perfect the right, title and interest of the Supplier in and to the Intellectual Property Rights in the Bespoke Software, the Tools and the Modified Software (Supplier).

The Customer shall use reasonable endeavours to prevent any infringement of the Supplier's Intellectual Property Rights in the System and shall promptly report to the Supplier any such infringement that comes to its attention. In particular, the Customer shall:

ensure that each Licensed User, before starting to use the System, is made aware that the System is proprietary to the Supplier (or appropriate third-party rights-owner) and that it may only be used and copied in accordance with this agreement;
implement suitable disciplinary procedures for employees who make unauthorised use or copies of the System, except as provided for in clause 19.1; and

not permit third parties to have access to the System without the prior written consent of the Supplier, who may require that such third party executes a written confidentiality agreement before being given access to the System.

The Supplier grants, subject to the terms of this agreement, the Customer [and its Affiliates] the non-exclusive, non-transferable right (subject to clause 32) to use the Licensed Software [on the Computer Hardware] and the Documentation for any purpose related to the Business (Licensed Purposes).

This is the most limited licence the supplier could give, as it is non-exclusive, non-transferable and limited to use of the software at the specified site, on the specified software, by a limited number of licensed users. It is likely that the customer will seek a broader licence, at least in relation to the software which it has paid to have written (Bespoke Software) or modified (Modified Software (Supplier).
For more information, see Drafting note, Licence of IPRs.

See also Drafting note, Consequences for licensors and licensees in the light of UsedSoft decision in particular the commentary on licence term and contractual provisions against transfer contained in the resources referred to there.

head.headtext: No fees payable for grant of software licence

para.paratext: There are no separate provisions for charging for the software licence, apart from a fee if the number of licensed users increases above the specified limit. (This assumes that the licence fee is a lump sum included in the price specified in Schedule 4) It is open to the parties to agree to reduce the initial price by providing for a royalty payable for use of the software. The pricing structure should be considered in line with each party's right to terminate the licence and the agreement separately from one another, see Drafting note, Termination.
The Licensed Software may be used only by Licensed Users [at the Site(s)], except as follows:

Clause 18.2 provides that the software must only be used by licensed users at the specified site, except in the circumstances set out in clause 18.2(a). These exceptions give the customer the necessary flexibility to run its business, including:
Moving.
Expanding the number of users.
Dealing with problems with the hardware or the site.
Replacing or upgrading the hardware.

This licence would not allow the customer to outsource operations using the system. Where the customer anticipates the possibility of such outsourcing, the supplier must negotiate suitable safeguards for its interests. For example, its confidential information will need protection if the company providing the outsourcing services is a competitor of the supplier. In addition, the supplier must be protected against (or recompensed for) wider use of the licensed software by the outsourcing company than is permitted by the licence. Where there is a maintenance contract, the supplier must be protected against increased demand for services.
the Licensed Software may be used on any replacement for all or any part of the Computer Hardware that has been provided, or approved in writing in advance, by the Supplier;

the Licence may, with the prior written consent of the Supplier, be extended to additional Licensed Users, and Schedule 5 may be amended accordingly, provided that any appropriate additional fee is paid to the Supplier before such use;

if the Customer transfers the whole of the Business permanently to another site, the Licensed Software may be used at the new site by the Licensed Users, provided that the Supplier is informed in writing of the change of site before use of the Licensed Software commences at the new site;

if the Computer Hardware becomes inoperable for any reason, the Licensed Software may be temporarily used on backup equipment until the Computer Hardware is repaired, and the Customer may use the Licensed Software for the purpose of testing whether any such backup equipment is suitable for use while the Computer Hardware is inoperable; and

if any Site becomes temporarily unusable due to flood, fire or similar damage, or an emergency situation, the Licensed Software may be used at an alternative site until the Site is again useable, provided that the Customer gives the Supplier notice of such alternative site and permits the Supplier to inspect such site once the Licensed Software is again in use at the Site to ensure that no copy of all or any part of the Licensed Software remains at the temporary site. If the alternative site is managed by a third party, the third party must have signed a confidentiality undertaking addressed to the Supplier to protect the Supplier's Confidential Information before the Licensed Software is transferred to the alternative site.

The Customer shall comply with the Third-Party Licences and shall indemnify and hold the Supplier harmless against any loss or damage which it may suffer or incur as a result of the Customer's breach of such terms howsoever arising.
The Supplier may treat the Customer's breach of any Third-Party Licence as a breach of this agreement.

head.headtext: Transfer or reproduction of Licensed Software
Transfer or reproduction of Licensed Software

para.paratext: If the supplier retains proprietary rights, it is necessary to find a balance between protection of these rights and the customer's need to make copies of the software for backup and security purposes.

The Customer may make such copies of the Licensed Software as are reasonably necessary for use in accordance with this agreement and for the purposes of backup and security. The Customer has no right to make, or authorise the making of, any other copies of the Licensed Software.

The Supplier shall at all times own all copies of all or any part of the Licensed Software. For copies recorded on a tangible medium, the Customer shall place on each copy of all or any part of the Licensed Software a clearly visible label indicating that the copy is the property of the Supplier and reproducing the Supplier's proprietary rights notice. For electronic copies, the Customer shall ensure that all proprietary notices contained in the Licensed Software shall be maintained in such copies and shall display when the software is run, in the same way as in the case of the Licensed Software as supplied by the Supplier. The Customer shall keep all copies of the Licensed Software in a secure place when not in use and shall, at all times, keep all such copies in its possession or control.
The Customer shall not:
sub-license, rent, lend, assign or transfer in any other way this agreement or the Licensed Software to any person without the prior written consent of the Supplier; and

See Drafting note, Consequences for licensors and licensees in the light of UsedSoft decision, in particular the commentary on contractual provisions against transfer contained in the resources referred to there.
give access to the Licensed Software through any network of computers to users who are not employees or agents of the Customer.

Clause 19.3(b) deals with a situation where the software is used on a network, in particular where that network is accessible to people other than the customer's employees, for example over the internet.

head.headtext: Use and adaptation of Licensed Software
Use and adaptation of Licensed Software

para.paratext: Clause 20.2 and clause 20.3 mean that the customer is not able to perform maintenance or upgrading of the software itself without express consent from the supplier.
The Customer may use the Licensed Software with other software.
The Customer may not make adaptations or variations of the Licensed Software without the prior consent of the Supplier.
The Customer may not disassemble, decompile, reverse translate or in any other manner decode the Licensed Software, except as permitted by law.

The law grants customers of software certain rights to copy, adapt and decompile software, some of which cannot be excluded by law (see Practice note, Main issues in software licensing and maintenance contracts: Acts specifically permitted and Practice note, Legal protection of software: Permitted acts).

The Supplier shall supply the Customer with New Releases in machine-readable form together with related amendments to the Documentation. The Supplier may make such New Releases available for downloading over the internet and will promptly notify the Customer when such downloads are available.
The Supplier shall notify the Customer promptly in writing of the issue of any New Version, specifying the following:
the charge for delivery and installation of the New Version;
the licence fee payable for the New Version;
in what way the New Version differs from the previous version in terms of functionality, performance and compatibility;
the terms on which the Supplier will make the New Version available.
For the avoidance of doubt, nothing in this agreement shall oblige the Supplier to provide, or the Customer to take, any New Version.

The standard document distinguishes between new releases and new versions, a separate fee being paid for the latter but not the former. The supplier is not obliged to supply, and the customer is not obliged to take, any new version (clause 21.3).

Support services may include installation of new releases (clause 21.1), particularly where the system is complex or the customer does not have its own in-house IT support. Documentation for new functionality should be provided with each update. It is usually provided in electronic form. If there is a significant change in the system as a result of a new release, the customer may require extra training which is typically provided at an additional charge.
[The Supplier shall ensure that support is available by telephone, email and fax during Normal Working Hours to provide assistance to the Customer in respect of the following:
remedying Defects in the Supported Software; and
providing advice on the use of the Supported Software.]

[The Supplier shall use reasonable endeavours to correct Defects notified to it by the Customer in a timely manner appropriate to the seriousness of the circumstances in accordance with the following procedure:

the Customer shall promptly notify the Supplier of all Defects. Where such notification is made orally, the Customer shall provide written confirmation (which may be sent by fax or by email) of the notification within [two] working days;

within [two] hours of such notification, the Supplier shall acknowledge receipt of the notification and shall determine, in consultation with the Customer, how seriously the Defect affects the Customer's operations;

if a notified Defect halts or substantially impairs the Customer's operations which use the Supported Software, the Supplier shall start work on correcting the Defect within [four] hours of receipt of such notification, shall use all reasonable efforts to correct the Defect as soon as possible and shall keep the Customer informed of progress towards the correction of the Defect;

if a notified Defect, while not halting or substantially impairing the Customer's operations, causes those operations to become significantly slowed or causes substantial inconvenience, the Supplier shall commence work on correcting the Defect within [48] hours of receipt of such notification and shall use all reasonable efforts to correct the Defect as soon as possible; and

in the case of Defects other than those specified in clause 21.5(c) and clause 21.5(d), the Supplier shall start work on correcting the Defect as soon as the Supplier's workload allows and shall use commercially reasonable efforts to correct the Defect.]

Very simple provisions for support services are contained in clause 21.4 and clause 21.5. Where the system is complex, especially where the customer's business could be seriously affected by a failure of the system, it is advisable to have a separate maintenance contract with detailed performance provisions in which both service levels and service credits can be defined (see Drafting note, Structure and content of agreement). For more information on service credits, see Practice note, Interest clauses: Too high: interest may be unenforceable as a penalty.

Clause 21.4 states generally what services the supplier will provide. Clause 21.5 will be important to the customer as it provides the performance standards, such as time for response and an escalation of efforts to fix defects, depending on how seriously the defect affects the operation of the system. The specified timings are usually the subject of negotiation. Where the supplier and the customer are in different time zones, there will be negotiation about the hours during which the supplier will respond to requests for assistance and, if times are to run outside the supplier's normal working hours, the supplier will no doubt cost this into the price for support services.
For more information, see Drafting note, Defect.

The Supplier shall use reasonable efforts to ensure the accurate migration of any data, but gives no warranties as to the completeness or accuracy of such migration. The Customer shall be responsible for checking the accuracy and completeness of the migrated data and shall promptly give sufficient details to the Supplier of any inaccuracies or omissions in order to permit the Supplier to correct them. If such data includes personal data, the Supplier shall return all copies of such personal data to the Customer on completion of the data migration process.
Delete this clause if no training is to be provided. The wording in square brackets in clause 22.1 should be deleted if there is no separate charge for training.

If the provisions for training are complex they should be included in Schedule 3. The supplier should agree a timetable with the customer and specify the location of the training and the maximum size of any training class. Where the training is included in the total price, the supplier should also specify the number of working hours of training provided for that price. If there are different elements of training, depending on the needs of particular classes of customer employees, Schedule 3 should contain a mechanism for the customer to request different types of training.
The Supplier undertakes to provide the Training to the Customer [in consideration of the Training charges specified in Schedule 4].
Any additional training required by the Customer shall be provided by the Supplier at the Supplier's standard rates then in force.

Training shall be carried out at [the Site(s) OR the Supplier's premises OR location(s) specified in Schedule 3], or as may otherwise be agreed by the Customer. Any special equipment necessary for the Training shall be provided by the Supplier.

head.headtext: Supplier personnel: System and support services

para.paratext: The Supplier undertakes that its employees and contractors, while on the Site(s) or any other premises of the Customer, will comply with all relevant rules and regulations laid down by the Customer from time to time for the behaviour of its own employees [and contractors], as notified reasonably in advance to the Supplier in writing to the Supplier from to time. [Access to the same via the Customer's intranet shall be deemed to satisfy such notification requirement.] The Supplier shall remove any employee or contractor whom the Customer can demonstrate has failed to comply with such rules, regulations and requirements.

The Supplier alone shall be responsible for the supervision, direction, control, wages, taxes, national insurance and benefits of [the Support Manager and] the Support Staff. The Supplier assumes full responsibility for their acts and omissions and acknowledges that they are not employees or agents of the Customer.

During the term of this agreement and for a period of six months after its termination neither party shall, without the prior written consent of the other, solicit, or permit any Affiliate or Associate to solicit, the employment of any person who is employed by the other party in the course of developing, supplying, maintaining or supporting the Supplier Software or any part of it.

The optional non-solicitation provisions in clause 23.3 are primarily for the protection of the supplier. It is common for customers to want to hire the key supplier employee who has been responsible for the system integration once the system is up and running, as this enables them to bypass the supplier for much of the ongoing maintenance.

However, where the project introduces the supplier to a new market, the customer may find that the supplier wants to hire key customer personnel in order to develop other clients in that market and so will need this non-solicitation clause. The clause should always be mutual, and care should be taken to make the period reasonable. It should be proportionate to the importance of the system to the customer's business and the length of time taken to complete the system integration project. If a court determines that either the period or scope of the restraint is not reasonable, it will be unenforceable.

Good management of the project is vital to its success. This requires active involvement from both the supplier and the user, with backing from senior management in both cases. Many failed software development projects are the result of the customer thinking that it can leave everything to the supplier.
No later than [five days] after the Commencement Date, the Customer shall notify the Supplier of the name and qualifications of the person appointed as the Customer Representative.

The Supplier shall appoint the Project Manager, who shall have the responsibility and commensurate authority for the overall progress of the Work and to whom all questions regarding this agreement can be referred. The name and qualifications of the appointed individual shall be notified in writing to the Customer Representative.

Both parties have an interest in ensuring that the right people are appointed as customer representative and project manager (see clause 24.1 and clause 24.2), because if these people communicate well with each other, have the right competencies and have sufficient authority within their respective organisations, there is a very good chance the project will be successful. As the success of the project depends to a large extent on the ability of these two individuals to work together, the parties should consider adding a mechanism for senior management to intervene and replace one or both of them if there is a serious personality clash.

The Customer Representative shall co-operate with the Project Manager and shall attend meetings scheduled by the Project Manager at reasonable intervals not less than once a week to advise and assist the Supplier on all matters relating to the Work.
The provision of employees, subcontractors and agents of the Supplier to carry out the Work shall be at the discretion of the Supplier.
The Supplier agrees that the Project Manager [and [SPECIFY KEY STAFF]] shall not be replaced before the Acceptance Date without notice to the Customer, unless:
the individual to be replaced is prevented by ill-health from carrying out their duties in connection with the agreement for a significant period;
the individual resigns from employment with the Supplier;
the contract of employment of the individual is terminated; or

the Customer makes a reasonable, written request to the Supplier to replace the individual because they have performed unsatisfactorily or have caused a breach of any of the Supplier's obligations under this agreement howsoever arising.

In the interest of a successful outcome (which both parties share), it is reasonable to have a contractual agreement that the supplier will not remove the project manager (or any other key member of its team) from the project before final acceptance (see clause 24.5). This is to ensure that highly skilled personnel, who are essential to the success of the project, are not reassigned by the supplier if a more lucrative project comes along. However, the supplier will usually resist agreeing to an absolute prohibition on moving personnel between projects (which could make its business impossible to manage efficiently). However, it should be prepared to agree that a few key individuals (and certainly the project manager) will not be removed without the customer's consent. There should also be a mechanism for allowing the customer to request the removal of an individual and to be consulted about any proposed replacement before the change is made.
If any such person is replaced, the Supplier shall consult with the Customer Representative about the identity of a suitable replacement.
The Customer agrees that the Customer Representative [and [SPECIFY KEY STAFF]] shall not be replaced before the Acceptance Date without notice to the Supplier, unless:
the individual to be replaced is prevented by ill-health from carrying out their duties in connection with the agreement for a significant period;
the individual resigns from employment with the Customer;
the contract of employment of the individual is terminated; or

the Supplier makes a reasonable, written request to the Customer to replace the individual because they have performed unsatisfactorily or have caused a breach of any of the Customer's obligations under this agreement howsoever arising.
The Customer shall consult with the Project Manager about the identity of a suitable replacement.
The Supplier shall:
take all reasonable steps to maintain continuity in relation to the Support Staff team; and
to the extent possible, give the Customer reasonable written notice of any proposed holiday or leave of absence to be taken by the Support Manager.

During the term in which the Support Services are to be provided under clause 33.2, the Customer shall not, without the Supplier's prior written approval, allow any person other than a representative of the Supplier to modify, repair or maintain any part of the Supported Software.

head.headtext: Customer not to modify Supported Software

para.paratext: The supplier is likely to insist on including clause 25.1, otherwise it could incur considerable expense trying to find out what the unauthorised third party has done in order to put it right.

The Customer shall co-operate with the Supplier in any manner reasonably required by the Supplier in order to carry out the Work, including provision of information and data, making available suitably qualified employees and contractors of the Customer and, subject to the Supplier's compliance with the Customer's normal security requirements [as specified in Schedule 3]:

provide access to the Customer's systems for the purpose of carrying out diagnostics and correction of Defects, provided that such access shall be direct or remote, at the Customer's option, and that, in the latter case, it will be subject to the Supplier's compliance with any additional requirements for security and encryption techniques or software which may from time to time be specified by the Customer;

provide such further access for the Support Staff to the Site(s) as is necessary to carry out the Supplier's obligations under this agreement. The Customer shall obtain for the Supplier all permissions necessary to obtain such access;
when the Support Staff are working on the Site(s), provide facilities and supplies reasonably required by the Supplier, such as power and computer consumables.

The Customer shall, at its own expense, provide the equipment necessary at the Site(s) to enable the access referred to in clause 25.2(a) in accordance with the specifications set out in the Business Requirements Specification, but all other costs and expenses for such access shall be borne by the Supplier.

The supplier will need access to the system in order to correct defects. Where possible, remote access should be provided so that the supplier's employees do not have to spend time travelling to the customer's facility in order to work on the system. However, in these circumstances it is likely that the supplier will need to comply with additional security requirements. It is important to have one person at the customer (or a limited number of specified individuals) responsible for passing requests for assistance to the supplier and feeding back the responses, so that both the customer and the supplier can control and monitor the work that is being done on systems support.
The Customer may, acting reasonably, restrict access to certain areas of its premises or systems on security grounds.

The Customer shall, no later than the Support Commencement Date, appoint and maintain for the duration of the agreement an individual to serve as primary contact with the Supplier for the purpose of the provision of services under this agreement, and a deputy to that individual, and shall notify the Supplier of the names of those individuals promptly on their appointment.
The Customer shall comply, as soon as reasonably practicable, with all the Supplier's reasonable requests for information or assistance.
For more information on this clause, see:
The drafting notes in Standard clause, Confidentiality.
Practice note, Boilerplate: do I really need this clause and why?: Confidentiality.

Confidential Information means all confidential information (however recorded or preserved) disclosed by a party or its Representatives (as defined below) to the other party and that party's Representatives [whether before or] [after the date of this agreement] in connection with [DESCRIBE TRANSACTION OR CONTRACT], including but not limited to:
the [existence and] terms of this agreement [or any agreement entered into in connection with this agreement];
any information that would be regarded as confidential by a reasonable business person relating to:

the business, assets, affairs, customers, clients, suppliers, [or] plans [, intentions, or market opportunities] of the disclosing party [(or of any member of the group of companies to which the disclosing party belongs)]; and

the operations, processes, product information, know-how, designs, trade secrets or software of the disclosing party [(or of any member of the group of companies to which the disclosing party belongs)];
any information developed by the parties in the course of carrying out this agreement; and
any information detailed in Schedule [NUMBER].
Representatives means, in relation to a party, its employees, officers, contractors, subcontractors, representatives and advisers.
The provisions of this clause shall not apply to any Confidential Information that:
is or becomes generally available to the public (other than as a result of its disclosure by the receiving party or its Representatives in breach of this clause);
was available to the receiving party on a non-confidential basis before disclosure by the disclosing party;

was, is or becomes available to the receiving party on a non-confidential basis from a person who, to the receiving party's knowledge, is not bound by a confidentiality agreement with the disclosing party or otherwise prohibited from disclosing the information to the receiving party; [or]
the parties agree in writing is not confidential or may be disclosed[; or]
is developed by or for the receiving party independently of the information disclosed by the disclosing party.
Each party shall keep the other party's Confidential Information secret and confidential and shall not:

use such Confidential Information except for [the purpose of exercising or performing its rights and obligations under or in connection with this agreement OR [SPECIFY PURPOSE]] (Permitted Purpose); or
disclose such Confidential Information in whole or in part to any third party, except as expressly permitted by this clause 26.
A party may disclose the other party's Confidential Information to those of its Representatives who need to know such Confidential Information for the Permitted Purpose, provided that:
it informs such Representatives of the confidential nature of the Confidential Information before disclosure; and
at all times, it is responsible for such Representatives' compliance with the confidentiality obligations set out in this clause.

A party may disclose Confidential Information to the extent such Confidential Information is required to be disclosed by law, by any governmental or other regulatory authority (including, without limitation, [ANY RELEVANT SECURITIES EXCHANGES]) or by a court or other authority of competent jurisdiction provided that, to the extent it is legally permitted to do so, it gives the other party as much notice of the disclosure as possible [and, where notice of disclosure is not prohibited and is given in accordance with this clause 26.5, it takes into account the reasonable requests of the other party in relation to the content of the disclosure].

A party may, provided that it has reasonable grounds to believe that the other party is involved in activity that may constitute a criminal offence under the Bribery Act 2010, disclose Confidential Information to the Serious Fraud Office without first informing the other party of such disclosure.

Each party reserves all rights in its Confidential Information. No rights or obligations in respect of a party's Confidential Information other than those expressly stated in this [clause OR agreement] are granted to the other party, or to be implied from this agreement.
On termination [or expiry] of this agreement, each party shall:
destroy or return to the other party all documents and materials (and any copies) containing, reflecting, incorporating or based on the other party's Confidential Information;

erase all the other party's Confidential Information from computer and communications systems and devices used by it, including such systems and data storage services provided by third parties (to the extent technically and legally practicable); and

certify in writing to the other party that it has complied with the requirements of this clause, provided that a recipient party may retain documents and materials containing, reflecting, incorporating or based on the other party's Confidential Information to the extent required by law or any applicable governmental or regulatory authority. The provisions of this clause shall continue to apply to any such documents and materials retained by a recipient party, subject to clause 38 (Termination).

Nothing in this agreement shall prevent either party from using any Tools, knowledge of which is contained in the unaided memory of such party's personnel [or those of its Affiliates] developed or disclosed under this agreement, provided that in doing so such party does not breach its obligations of confidentiality under this clause 26 or breach any Intellectual Property Rights of the other party [or any of its Affiliates]. An individual's memory is only "unaided" with respect to any information if the individual has not retained a copy of the information and has not intentionally memorised that information other than is required to perform the Services.

This optional clause allows each party to use the software tools to the extent that they reside in the unaided memory of the relevant person, that is, unprompted by, for example, a written record of the relevant information. Consider this text carefully before including it. If a party claims that particular information was not in the unaided memory of the relevant person, it is difficult to disprove this. Also ensure that any finally negotiated text here is consistent with clause 26.
Except as expressly stated in this agreement, no party makes any express or implied warranty or representation concerning its Confidential Information.

No party shall make, or permit any person to make, any public announcement concerning this agreement without the prior written consent of the other parties (such consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed), except as required by law, any governmental or regulatory authority (including, without limitation, any relevant securities exchange), any court or other authority of competent jurisdiction.
The provisions of this clause 26 shall [continue to apply after termination [or expiry] of this agreement OR survive for a period of [five] years from termination [or expiry] of this agreement].

The supplier may not want to offer this clause in the initial draft, particularly where the customer is a well-known company, but it is reasonable for customers to want to vet what the supplier says to third parties about them and their system.
For information on announcements clauses, see the integrated drafting notes to Standard clause, Announcements.
The provisions of this clause 26 shall [continue to apply after termination [or expiry] of this agreement OR survive for a period of [five] years from termination [or expiry] of this agreement].
For more information on data protection, and the appropriate clauses to be inserted here, see Drafting note, Data protection.
[INSERT APPROPRIATE DATA PROTECTION CLAUSES, SEE DRAFTING NOTE].

Neither party shall export, directly or indirectly, any technical data acquired from the other party under this agreement (or any products, including software, incorporating any such data) in breach of any applicable laws or regulations (Export Control Laws), including United States export laws and regulations, to any country for which the United States or any other government or any agency thereof at the time of export requires an export licence or other governmental approval without first obtaining such licence or approval.

Technology export control laws are becoming increasingly pervasive and stringent around the world. In the UK, for example, there is the Export Control Act 2002 (and various orders made under it) and similar laws in the US include the Export Administration Regulations and the International Traffic in Arms Regulations. Under US law a restricted asset may be deemed to be exported in a variety of circumstances, such as where services are performed by a non-US national outside of the US and this involves remote access to restricted assets in the US. For example, a software engineer in South East Asia might access a computer in the US for the purpose of performing maintenance on a restricted piece of software.
Consider including a mutual indemnity, if there is a particular concern in this area.
Each party undertakes:
contractually to oblige any third party to whom it discloses or transfers any such data or products to make an undertaking to it in similar terms to the one set out above; and

if requested, to provide the other party with any reasonable assistance, at the reasonable cost of the other party, to enable it to perform any activity required by any competent government or agency in any relevant jurisdiction for the purpose of compliance with any Export Control Laws.
In performing its obligations under this agreement the [Supplier OR Customer] shall comply with the Mandatory Policies.

This clause can be used where the customer or supplier has specific business policies and wants to ensure that the other party complies with them. The policies might reflect a party's legal obligations, for instance, its obligations under instruments such as the Modern Slavery Act 2015, the Bribery Act 2010 or the data protection legislation. Alternatively, a party may have adopted business social responsibility policies voluntarily.

In most goods or services agreements, the obligation is usually on the supplier to comply with the customer's policies. But this may not always be the case: depending on the bargaining strengths of the parties, a supplier may well require the customer to comply with the supplier's policies instead. As this is a pro-supplier agreement, the supplier may want to omit this clause altogether from the first draft provided to the customer.
If the supplier does choose to include this clause, there are two drafting options:

The first is a requirement on the customer to comply with the supplier's policies. This is slightly unusual (the usual position is that a supplier agrees to comply with the customer's policies), but a supplier who is concerned about its reputation may well want to ensure that it is only supplying goods or services to customers who are willing to comply with the supplier's policies on issues such as anti-bribery, modern slavery and ethics.

The second option is a requirement on the supplier to comply with the customer's policies. This is the more usual approach in a goods or services agreement. A supplier may include this option if, for instance, it has already agreed in principle that it is able to comply with the customer's policies, or the parties already have an ongoing relationship where the supplier is comfortable with complying with the customer's policies.
Whatever approach is taken, check that the definition of "Mandatory Policies" above is consistent with the approach in this clause.

Note also that if the customer agrees to comply with the supplier's policies, the supplier may want a subsequent right to terminate the agreement if the customer breaches those policies. If this is desired, the supplier could include this additional right to terminate at clause 34. For an example of this, see Standard document, Simple framework services agreement (pro-supplier) clause 15.3.
For more information on general compliance clauses, see the integrated drafting notes to Standard clause, Compliance with laws and policies.
These provisions must be read in conjunction with the general limitation of liability (see Drafting note, Limitation of liability).

The warranty under clause 29.1(a) is a form of warranty of title, which is normally implied by statute and is not usually possible to exclude. The advantage of giving an express warranty is that the remedy for breach can be limited in the way it is here. Also, the express exclusion of other warranties under clause 29.4 is more likely to be deemed reasonable (and therefore enforceable) if a reasonable warranty of performance has been given. Another advantage of giving an express warranty is that the remedy for breach can be limited, either by monetary amount or by the action to be taken by the supplier, as here. Clause 29.5 is an important protection for the supplier, who should never promise to fix all defects, as this may be impossible. Similarly, the supplier should not agree to rush to fix defects which do not significantly affect the customer's use of the system.

Suppliers may try to avoid giving any warranties as to performance, such as those in clause 29.1(c), but excluding all liability for performance by the supplier may be held by a court to be unreasonable and thus unenforceable. If satisfactory express warranties are given, it is reasonable for the customer to agree to the express exclusion of other warranties (clause 29.4). The supplier may try to exclude all liability if the customer makes unauthorised modifications of the system.
Clause 29.6 and clause 29.7 provide the usual exemptions for the supplier regarding unauthorised use or modifications made by the customer.

The modified software (third party) and the third-party software are not covered by the warranties in clause 29.1. The customer should seek to rely on warranties given by the relevant third party in the licence agreement between the third party and the customer. If the customer agrees to do so, it might nevertheless ask the supplier to pass on to the customer any warranties given to the supplier by the third party. The supplier's response to such a request may turn on the covenant strength of the third-party licensor.
The Supplier warrants and represents that:

the Licensed Software and Documentation are proprietary to the Supplier (except where otherwise stated in Schedule 1) and that, as far as it is aware, it has the right to license all [UK] Intellectual Property Rights in and to the Licensed Software and Documentation to the Customer and to provide the Support Services to the Customer;
as far as it is aware, none of the Licensed Software or Documentation supplied by the Supplier under this agreement infringes the [UK] Intellectual Property Rights of any third party;
Rather than give the warranty in clause 29.1(b) the supplier may prefer, instead, to rely on the indemnity to be provided under clause 30. This will depend on the negotiating power of the parties.
the System at the Acceptance Date, and for [six] months after that date, will perform in all material respects in accordance with the Technical Specification;

it will perform the Support Services in a timely, reliable and professional manner, in conformity with Good Industry Practice by a sufficient number of competent Support Staff with appropriate skills, qualifications and experience, and has and will at all times have the ability and capacity to meet such requirements;
it is in compliance with, and will perform the Support Services in compliance with, all applicable law and regulations (save for Cybersecurity Laws); and
the Customer will receive good and valid title to all deliverables in connection with the Support Services, free and clear of all encumbrances and liens of any kind.
The sole remedies for breach of the warranties in clause 29.1(a) [and clause 29.1(b)] are set out in clause 30.

The sole remedy for breach of the warranty under clause 7.2 and this clause 29.1(c) shall be correction of Defects by the Supplier within a reasonable time from notification by the Customer of the Defect that constitutes such breach.

The warranties set out in clause 29.1 are in lieu of all other express or implied warranties or conditions, including implied warranties or conditions of satisfactory quality and fitness for a particular purpose, in relation to this agreement. Without limitation, the Supplier specifically denies any implied or express representation that the System will be fit:

to operate in conjunction with any hardware items or software products other than with those hardware items and software products that are identified in the Documentation as being compatible with the System; or
to operate uninterrupted or error-free.

The Supplier does not warrant or guarantee that it will be able to rectify all Defects, nor that any Defect which does not materially affect the Customer's operations using the Supported Software will be corrected before the issue of the next New Release.

Any unauthorised modifications, use or improper installation of the System by or on behalf of the Customer shall render all the Supplier's warranties and obligations under this agreement null and void.

The Supplier shall not be obliged to rectify any particular Defect if attempts to rectify such Defect other than normal recovery or diagnostic procedures have been made by the Customer's personnel or third parties without the permission of the Supplier.

The Customer acknowledges that the only warranties in relation to the Third-Party Software and the Modified Software (Third Party) or the supply thereof are those contained in the licence from the third-party supplier(s) of the same, and that to the extent that any of such warranties are given to the Supplier, it will pass on the benefit of such warranties to the Customer [and its Affiliates].

Any Open-Source Software provided by the Supplier shall be used according to the terms and conditions of the specific licence under which the relevant Open-Source Software is distributed, but is provided "as is" and expressly subject to the disclaimer in clause 29.4.
Save in respect of any specific warranties given elsewhere in this agreement, the Supplier does not warrant or guarantee that the System, when taken in whole or in part, will:
comply with Cybersecurity Laws, or
contain no Vulnerabilities,

and it shall be the Customer's sole responsibility to ensure that the Business Requirements Specification and/or the Technical Specification detail all of the Customer's cybersecurity requirements, including any requirements that might be imposed on the Customer's business, operations or systems under Cybersecurity Laws, in sufficient detail so they can be implemented by the Supplier as part of the Work.

Various pieces of legislation effective in the UK (such as the NIS Regulations and the retained EU law version of the GDPR (UK GDPR)) impose certain minimum security standards on networks and information systems (including those that process personal data). A breach of these provisions can attract substantial fines (up to Â£17.5 million or 4% of total worldwide annual turnover, in the case of UK GDPR and up to Â£17 million in the case of the NIS Regulations). For more information, see Drafting note, Data protection and Drafting note, Network and Information Systems Regulations 2018.

These security requirements are very rarely prescriptive, and (broadly speaking) require in-scope organisations to implement appropriate and proportionate technical and organisational measures to manage risks posed to the security of the network and information systems on which their service relies (in the case of the NIS Regulations) and to protect against unauthorised or unlawful processing of personal data and against accidental loss or destruction of, or damage to, personal data (in the case of the UK GDPR).

Such measures must have regard to the state of the art, and (in the case of the UK GDPR) organisations are entitled to consider the costs of implementation in deciding what measures are appropriate in the circumstances. In the case of the NIS Regulations, OESs must have regard to any relevant guidance issued by their relevant competent authority and RDSPs must take into account compliance with international standards.

Accordingly, "appropriate and proportionate" measures are likely to change over time, based on new published guidance, developments in technology and the available state of the art (particularly for major projects, extended over a year or more).

For these reasons, suppliers are likely to want to resist any attempt by the customer to make them liable for any breach of these security standards, unless such requirements have been agreed in advance by the parties as part of the Business Requirements Specification or the Technical Specification, and particular limits of liability have been agreed in relation to the allocation of any regulatory fines, and other liabilities, that might result from any such security issues. The supplier will most likely want to argue that it is the customer who understands its own business operations (and its reliance on the System as part of those business operations) the best, in order to decide what security measures are appropriate in the circumstances. Alternatively, the supplier may wish to charge the customer an additional consulting fee for providing cybersecurity advice.

With this in mind, we have included an optional carve-out in clause 29.10 to make it clear that the supplier is not taking any responsibility for cyber-issues unless these requirements form part of the Business Requirements Specification or the Technical Specification, which the supplier has signed off on.

Where the supplier is providing maintenance, or hosting, services, and one of the objectives of that service is to safeguard the System against cyber-risks and attacks, the customer may try to impose certain cyber obligations on the supplier as part of the service warranties to be agreed. We recommend such obligations are restricted to the taking of such reasonable steps that a supplier should be expected to take to safeguard against cyber incidents in accordance with good industry practice, to be judged contemporaneously at the time the service is provided (as cyber standards are bound to change over time).
The Customer:

warrants to the Supplier that it will at all times comply with all applicable laws and regulations with respect to its activities under this agreement and in connection with any part of the Supplier Software;
shall take reasonable steps not to introduce any Virus or Vulnerability to the Supplier Software or the network and information systems of the Supplier;

shall indemnify the Supplier against all liabilities, costs, expenses, damages and losses (including any direct, indirect or consequential losses, loss of profit, loss of reputation and all interest, penalties and legal and other [reasonable] professional costs and expenses) suffered or incurred by the Supplier arising out of any non-compliance by the Customer with this clause 29.11.

Each party warrants that it has full capacity and authority, and all necessary licences, permits and consents, to enter into and perform this agreement, and that those signing this agreement are duly authorised to bind the party for whom they sign.

The Supplier shall indemnify the Customer for any amounts awarded against the Customer in judgment or settlement of any claim arising out of or in connection with any claim that the Customer's use of the Licensed Software or Documentation, or the Customer's receipt of the benefit of the Services, in each case in accordance with this agreement, infringed a third party's Intellectual Property Rights, provided that, if any third party makes a claim, or notifies an intention to make a claim, against the Customer which may reasonably be considered likely to give rise to a liability under this indemnity (Claim), the Customer:

This clause provides the customer with protection in the form of an indemnity against third-party claims that its use of the licensed software infringes the IPRs belonging to that third party (see Practice note, Main issues in software licensing and maintenance contracts: Intellectual property and indemnities). The supplier will usually be prepared to meet the customer's concerns in this respect, at least as far as any licensed software is concerned, although the exact scope of that protection will be the subject of negotiation and the supplier may seek various exclusions â see Drafting note, Exclusions.

The customer may push for the indemnity to cover the entire system (not just the software which is licensed under clause 18.1) but the supplier may require the customer to rely on any separate indemnity to be provided by the relevant third party software licensor under the customer's direct licence with that third party.

From the supplier's perspective, it is important to ensure that there is nothing in the agreement (in particular, clause 30 or clause 31) that provides that the cap on liability in clause 31.5 does not apply to the supplier's liability under clause 30. Conversely, the customer will want to ensure that there is such a provision.

The proviso to clause 30.1 outlines the procedure to be adopted when a third party notifies the customer of an alleged IPR infringement. It is drafted as a proviso to the indemnity obligation so that, if the customer does not meet any such condition, the supplier is no longer obliged to fulfil that obligation.
as soon as reasonably practicable, gives written notice of the Claim to the Supplier, specifying the nature of the Claim in reasonable detail;

does not make any admission of liability, agreement or compromise in relation to the Claim without the prior written consent of the Supplier (such consent not to be unreasonably conditioned, withheld or delayed);

gives the Supplier and its professional advisers access at reasonable times (on reasonable prior notice) to its premises and its officers, directors, employees, agents, representatives or advisers, and to any relevant assets, accounts, documents and records within the power or control of the Customer, so as to enable the Supplier and its professional advisers to examine them and to take copies (at the Supplier's expense) for the purpose of assessing the Claim; and

subject to the Supplier providing security to the Customer to the Customer's reasonable satisfaction against any claim, liability, costs, expenses, damages or losses which may be incurred, takes such action as the Supplier may reasonably request to avoid, dispute, compromise or defend the Claim.

Under clause 30.1(d) the supplier will want to have control of any litigation, as the outcome will determine the extent of its liability under clause 30.1. However, the customer may wish to retain control to avoid protracted litigation and possible harm to its reputation.
Without prejudice to clause 29.6, the Supplier shall not in any circumstances have any Claim:

caused or contributed to by the Customer's use of the Licensed Software, Documentation or Services in combination with software not supplied or approved in writing by the Supplier (other than the operating system of any Computer Hardware, provided that the Supplier was notified in writing of the identity of this operating system before this agreement was entered into);
based on use of any version of the Licensed Software other than the latest version supplied by the Supplier, if such claim could have been avoided by the use of such supplied version; or
where the claim for infringement arises in respect of a feature of the System which was specified by the Customer in the Business Requirements Specification.

head.headtext: Exclusions from the intellectual property rights indemnity

para.paratext: Clause 30.2 ensures that the supplier does not have liability if the third-party infringement claim arises from something the customer has done outside the authorised or expected use of the software, or from a feature insisted on by the customer.
It is reasonable for the supplier to take liability for any infringement which might arise from the combination of any software licensed and the operating software of the system hardware.

During the tendering process the customer should have notified the supplier of any existing software with which the new system is to work in conjunction, as this is relevant to operability issues. Once the system is accepted, it should have a way of notifying the supplier of any new software it is considering installing.

If use of the Licensed Software, Documentation or receipt of the benefit of the Support Services becomes, or, in the opinion of qualified legal counsel, is likely to become, the subject of any such claim, the Supplier may:
replace all or part of the System or Documentation or Services with functionally equivalent software, documentation or services without any charge to the Customer;

modify the System or Documentation or Services as necessary to avoid such claim, provided that the System, documentation or services (as amended) functions in substantially the same way as they did before modification;
procure for the Customer a licence from the relevant claimant to continue using the System, Documentation or Services (as the case may be).

head.headtext: Remedies if the licensed software infringes

para.paratext: If the infringement action succeeds, the customer may face an injunction preventing it from using the infringing software. At worst, this could make the entire system unusable. The supplier will typically accept an obligation to take reasonable steps to keep the system usable, either by taking a licence from the third party or by replacing or modifying the system to avoid infringement. If none of these are reasonably achievable, the customer will seek to be in a position where it can obtain a non-infringing alternative as soon as possible.
If:

head.headtext: Termination if infringement cannot be remedied

para.paratext: The supplier should seek to protect itself under the provisions of clause 30.4 which allow it to terminate the licence where the infringement cannot be remedied after use of best efforts. In this event, the customer will probably ask that the supplier repay some or all of the money the customer paid for the software, so it might be tactically prudent for the supplier to insert in its original draft a limited repayment provision, perhaps specifying an amount which decreases the longer the software has been in use.
use of the Licensed Software, Documentation or Services is determined in a court of law to be infringing;

the Supplier is advised by a barrister of at least ten years' call that use or possession by the Customer [or any of its Affiliates] of the Licensed Software or Documentation or Services in accordance with this agreement is likely to constitute infringement of a third party's rights; or

an injunction or similar order is granted in connection with any claim falling within the scope of clause 30.1 which prevents or restricts the use or possession by the Customer [or any of its Affiliates] of the Licensed Software or Documentation or Services in accordance with this Agreement,

and the Supplier is unable, after best efforts, to procure for the Customer the right to continue using the System or the Documentation or the Services, or to provide the Customer with functionally equivalent non-infringing software, documentation or services this agreement and the Licence will be terminated.

Notwithstanding any other provision in this agreement, clause 30.1 shall not apply to the extent that any claim or action referred to in that clause arises directly or indirectly through the possession, use, development, modification or maintenance of any Third-Party Software or Modified Software (Third-Party) or through the breach of any Third Party Licence by the Customer [or any of its Affiliates] howsoever arising.
Clause 30.5 confirms that the indemnity obligation does not extend to third party software.

The supplier will likely want to exclude any third party software from the scope of the indemnity, as the nature of the code in question is beyond its control, and any claims could be brought by the customer directly against the third party licensor under the relevant third party licence (see Clause 8.2). However, this exclusion (or any other attempt to limit the scope of the indemnity in such a way) may be resisted by the customer, particularly where the supplier is selling itself as providing an "overall solution".
For more information, see Drafting note, Warranties.

If a payment due from the Supplier under this clause is subject to tax (whether by way of direct assessment or withholding at its source), the Customer shall be entitled to receive from the Supplier such amounts as shall ensure that the net receipt, after tax, to the Customer in respect of the payment is the same as it would have been were the payment not subject to tax.

Nothing in this clause shall restrict or limit the Customer's general obligation at law to mitigate a loss it may suffer or incur as a result of an event that may give rise to a claim under this indemnity.
This clause is key to management of the Supplier's risk.

Ideally, the Supplier would want to exclude all its liability to the Customer, but the Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977 (UCTA) (where it applies) effectively prevents blanket exclusions and imposes a requirement of reasonableness as to the level of responsibility that the Supplier should bear.
For more information, see the following Practice notes relating to limiting liability in B2B contracts:
Main issues in systems integration contracts: Exclusions and limitation of liability.
Limiting liability: drafting and negotiating.
Limiting liability: statutory and common law controls on limitation clauses.
Limiting liability: interpretation.
See also the parts of these Practice notes referred to in the drafting notes relating to the specific clauses.
If service level arrangements feature in the agreement that you draft, consider adding a clause similar to Standard document, Application service provision agreement (pro-supplier): clause 12.4.
Except as expressly provided in this agreement and to the fullest extent permitted by applicable law:

the Customer shall be solely responsible, as against the Supplier, for any opinions, recommendations, forecasts or other conclusions made or actions taken by the Customer, any client of the Customer or any other third party based (wholly or in part) on the results obtained from the use of the System or the Services by the Customer;
the Supplier shall have no liability for any damage caused by errors or omissions in any information or instructions provided to the Supplier by the Customer in connection with the Services; and
all warranties, representations, conditions and all other terms of any kind whatsoever implied by statute or common law are excluded from this agreement.

Clause 31.1(c) seeks to exclude statutory implied terms, to the extent that this is legally possible. See Practice notes, Limiting liability: statutory and common law controls on limitation clauses: UCTA: breach of statutory implied terms as to quality in supply of goods and Supply of goods: statutory implied terms and Limiting liability: interpretation: "To the extent allowed by law".
Neither party excludes or limits liability to the other party for:
fraud or fraudulent misrepresentation;
death or personal injury caused by negligence;
a breach of any obligations implied by section 12 of the Sale of Goods Act 1979 or section 2 of the Supply of Goods and Services Act 1982; or
any matter for which it would be unlawful for the parties to exclude liability.

There are various types of loss for which liability must remain unlimited, because the law prevents them being excluded. See Practice notes, Limiting liability: drafting and negotiating: Must you expressly accept liabilities you cannot exclude? and Limiting liability: statutory and common law controls on limitation clauses: UCTA: breach of statutory implied terms as to title and possession in supply of goods.

Subject to clause 31.2, the Supplier shall not in any circumstances be liable whether in contract, tort (including for negligence and breach of statutory duty howsoever arising), misrepresentation (whether innocent or negligent), restitution or otherwise, for:
any loss (whether direct or indirect) of profits, business, business opportunities, revenue, turnover, reputation or goodwill;
any loss or corruption (whether direct or indirect) of data or information;
loss (whether direct or indirect) of anticipated savings or wasted expenditure (including management time); or
any loss or liability (whether direct or indirect) under or in relation to any other contract.
This clause seeks to exclude various categories of loss.

The distinction between direct and indirect loss is not clear cut and there is no easy formulation to determine on which side of the line a category or type of loss falls in any specific case. A particular difficulty arises when deciding whether loss of profits is direct or indirect. Accordingly, this clause seeks to exclude certain types of loss, whether direct or indirect. See Practice notes, Limiting liability: drafting and negotiating: Should you exclude indirect and consequential loss? and Be careful how you limit indirect and consequential loss and Limiting liability: interpretation: "Indirect and consequential loss".

This clause is drafted in the form of a series of sub-clauses with the aim that if one sub- clause is held unreasonable, it can be severed from the other provisions, which will remain enforceable. See Practice note, Limiting liability: drafting and negotiating: Drafting for enforceability.

Clear words must be used if an exclusion or restriction of liability for negligence is to be effective. See Practice note, Limiting liability: statutory and common law controls on limitation clauses: Negligence: express reference safest for exclusion.

The exclusion of liability for negligence is subject to the UCTA reasonableness test. See Practice notes, Limiting liability: statutory and common law controls on limitation clauses: UCTA: negligence and Limiting liability: drafting and negotiating: Surviving the UCTA reasonableness test.

Whether an exclusion or restriction of liability for deliberate breaches is effective is a matter of construction. However, clear words must be used. See Practice note, Limiting liability: statutory and common law controls on limitation clauses: Deliberate breach: clear words needed.
Clause 31.3 shall not prevent claims, which fall within the scope of clause 31.5, for:
direct financial loss that are not excluded under any of the categories set out in clause 31.3(a) to clause 31.3(d); or
tangible property or physical damage.

This clause expressly states that there are other types of loss for which liability has not been excluded-under clause 31.3, including loss of property. Case law indicates that making the distinction between non-recoverable types of loss and potentially recoverable types of loss should help support a supplier's argument that the clause is valid. See Practice note, Limiting liability: drafting and negotiating: Why expressly accept any liability? and Specific liabilities to consider identifying as acceptable if capped.

Subject to clause 31.2, the Supplier's total aggregate liability in contract [(including in respect of the indemnity at clause 30.1)], tort (including negligence and breach of statutory duty howsoever arising), misrepresentation (whether innocent or negligent), restitution or otherwise, arising in connection with the performance or contemplated performance of this agreement or any collateral contract shall be limited to Â£[AMOUNT].

This clause seeks to limit the Supplier's aggregate liability under the contract to a fixed amount. Suppliers typically set the liability cap at an amount equal to 100% of the total fees. For longer agreements (for example, two years or more) suppliers will generally prefer to have an annual liability cap linked to a variable amount. For an example of this drafting, see clauses 13.3(b), 13.3(c) and 13.4 in Standard document, SaaS subscription agreement (pro-supplier).

Whichever approach is taken, you will need to assess whether the limitation is likely to be enforceable, bearing in mind the reasonableness test under UCTA and the matters that were considered in St Albans City and District Council v International Computers Ltd [1995] FSR 686.

See Practice notes, Limiting liability: statutory and common law controls on limitation clauses: The UCTA reasonableness test, Factors relevant to UCTA reasonableness and Table of factors affecting UCTA reasonableness and Limiting liability: drafting and negotiating: Capping liability and the comments underlying the suggested liability cap in Standard document, Software development agreement (pro-customer): Limitation of liability: Drafting note.

If this provision is held to be unreasonable under UCTA, damages would be recoverable without limitation, based on the ordinary contract law rules of remoteness. See Practice note, Damages for breach of contract: an overview.

Where this standard document is being used to create a framework agreement, the Customer may seek to ensure that the individual liability caps that apply to each of the relevant countries in respect of provision of goods or services are cumulative. Alternatively, the Customer may seek provision for two types of liability cap: the individual caps referred to above, and an overall cap regarding all claims arising out of the provision of goods or services to all the relevant countries. Clarity on these issues should be mutually advantageous.
The customer may also seek to cap its liability to the supplier, for example, if it is concerned about its liability under its obligations to the supplier.
Regarding the first set of optional text concerning the indemnity at clause 31, see Practice note, Limiting liability: drafting and negotiating: Check interaction with indemnities.

The parties acknowledge and agree that any dates quoted for delivery of the Work or the Support Services are approximate only, and that the time of delivery is not of the essence. The Supplier shall not be liable for any delay in delivery of the Work or the Support Services that is caused by an event, circumstance or cause within the scope of clause 43 or the Customer's failure to provide the Supplier with adequate delivery instructions.
The aim of this clause is to limit the Supplier's liability for any delay in delivery. This limitation will be subject to the reasonableness requirement under UCTA (if applicable).
See Standard clause, Assignment and other dealings.

See Drafting note, Consequences for licensors and licensees in the light of UsedSoft decision, in particular the commentary on contractual provisions against transfer contained in the resources referred to there.

Subject to clause 32.2, this agreement is personal to the parties and neither party shall assign, transfer, mortgage, charge, subcontract, delegate, declare a trust of or deal in any other manner with any or all of its rights and obligations under this agreement without the prior written consent of the other party (such consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed).

Either party may assign or subcontract any or all of its rights and obligations under this agreement to a member of its Group for so long as that company remains a member of the assignor's group. The assignor shall procure that such company assigns any rights assigned to it in accordance with this clause 32.2 back to the assignor or another member of the assignor's Group immediately before it ceases to be a member of the assignor's Group. A party who subcontracts the performance of any or all of its obligations under this agreement to a member of its Group shall immediately resume the performance of such obligations on such company ceasing to be a member of its Group[, or delegate the performance of such obligations to such other member of its Group as it may nominate].]]

[Where a party requests consent to an assignment or subcontract pursuant to clause 31.1, then, to help the other party reach a decision on the proposed assignment or subcontract, the first party shall provide the other party [with a copy of any proposed assignment agreement or subcontract, together] with any information that the other party may reasonably require about the proposed assignee or subcontractor. [If the other party gives its consent to the assignment or subcontract, the first party shall implement an appropriate system of [due diligence,] [audit,] [and] [training] for its assignee or subcontractor designed to ensure its compliance with the other party's [SPECIFY RELEVANT BUSINESS POLICIES, E.G., ANTI-SLAVERY POLICY].]

Suppliers often rely on maintenance fees for a regular cash flow, so require at least a minimum period of maintenance and a fairly long period of notice if the customer decides to terminate the maintenance agreement. However, customers should avoid being tied to the supplier for maintenance indefinitely and need the right to terminate very quickly if the supplier fails to provide maintenance at all, or to provide it to an adequate standard or in a timely fashion.
Consider whether you need to make the operation of the agreement retrospective, for example, in relation to the confidentiality obligations.

This agreement shall, subject to clause 33.2, commence on the Commencement Date and shall continue, unless terminated earlier in accordance with its terms, including clause 34, until the Work has been completed.

The Support Services shall commence on the Support Commencement Date and shall continue until the Support Services are terminated in accordance with clause 34.5(b), unless terminated earlier in accordance with any of the other provisions of clause 34.
The Licence shall commence on the Commencement Date and shall continue in force until termination in accordance with this agreement, including clause 34.
This agreement covers three main supply obligations which are treated separately but are likely to be interlinked:
The provision of software development and system integration services.
The licensing of software (which may be pre-existing or still to be developed).
The provision of basic support services.
As such, the parties will need to consider how termination of one supply obligation will impact the others.
Clause 34 has been drafted on the basis that:

Any termination of the main agreement (which is primary concerned with software development and systems integration) should not necessarily terminate the customer's right to use any software already developed and provided to it (under the licence granted under clause 18.1) or any support services being paid for, separately, in relation to that software.

Any termination of the customer's licence to use the software should necessarily terminate the agreement and the support services, because they would be redundant without the customer first having the right to use the software.

However, the parties will need to consider whether the assumptions above are correct, bearing in mind the project being contemplated. Where the customer is expected to pay an additional value for the software licence (over and above the price of the development works) it may be easier for the customer to argue that the position above is fair. Otherwise, the supplier may argue that a breach of the customer's obligation to pay for certain development works should entitle the supplier to terminate the underlying licence as well as the development services.
The position of each party will likely depend on:
How each of the work streams has being valued, and how they are being paid for.

How interconnected each work stream is (for example, is the overall solution dependant on the successful completion of the development work, or would the solution still work even if the contemplated development work is unsuccessful?).
Whether the customer would be permitted to take any partially completed development work and appoint a replacement supplier to complete the project.

When drafting termination provisions the customer should also consider whether it requires materials to be held in escrow, and released upon termination, to enable (for example) another supplier to take over the project in future (see Drafting note, Escrow agreement).

The parties should consider the possible impact of the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 (SI 2006/246) (TUPE) on exit in the (unlikely but conceivable) event that one (or more) of the supplier's employees is sufficiently dedicated to supporting the customer to transfer to the customer or a new supplier when the contract comes to an end. The customer may seek an indemnity from the supplier to cover this position. For further information, see Practice notes, TUPE (3): service provision changes and Outsourcing agreements: drafting and negotiating employment indemnities and warranties.
There are various matters of general administration, including the return of software and confidential information (see clause 34.7 and clause 34.13).
Grounds for termination include:
Without cause, that is, for convenience (not usual in development projects, but relevant regarding maintenance and support arrangements).
For cause (for example, default).
Neutral, that is, force majeure.
(See clause 43.)

The grounds for termination include material or persistent breach. Overriding the contractual terms is the doctrine of fundamental breach, which in appropriate circumstances the customer might wish to invoke, bearing in mind that purporting to terminate on this ground when not justified in the circumstances may lead to the customer being in breach.

The terms "material breach" or a breach that is or is not "remediable" (both of which are used in clause 34.1(b)) or "repeatedly breaches" are not terms with precise legal definitions. It is not certain, for example, that a material breach equates to a repudiatory breach entitling the innocent party to terminate at common law. Consequently, there will always be some uncertainty as to the sorts of breaches that will give rise to the Supplier's right to terminate (see Peregrine Systems Ltd v Steria Ltd [2005] EWCA Civ 239 (see also Legal update: Court of Appeal confirms software contract wrongly terminated by defendant).

For further guidance on termination, see Standard clause, Termination and associated drafting notes, including information on the Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020, which came into force on 26 June 2020.
