See also Practice note, Restrictions on terminating supply contracts in insolvency proceedings and, in particular, What is a contract for the supply of goods and services? and the commentary around Software licence agreements and Intellectual property licence agreements.

Clauses dealing with change of control (see clause 34.5(a)) require care. Refer to the definition of Control and ensure that it is appropriate in this context as well as its use in relation to the definition of Affiliate.
Check each of the provisions of the agreement that are to survive termination under clause 34.10.

para.paratext: Without affecting any other right or remedy available to it, either party may terminate this agreement with immediate effect by giving [written] notice to the other party if:
the other party fails to pay any amount due under this agreement on the due date for payment and remains in default not less than [NUMBER] days after being notified [in writing] to make such payment;

the other party commits a material breach of any [other] term of this agreement and (if such breach is remediable) fails to remedy that breach within a period of [NUMBER] days after being notified [in writing] to do so;

It can be difficult for organisations (particularly suppliers) to agree to "delete" electronic data. The word âdeletionâ can mean different things in relation to electronic data, and it is recognised that it is not always possible to delete or erase all traces of the data. As the ICO (the UK's data protection authority) has opined that the term "deletion", in relation to personal data, should be taken to mean ensuring that the data is beyond use, we consider this is a reasonable deletion standard to use in most circumstances. If it is appropriate to delete personal data from a live system, we recommend that a party should also be expected to delete it from any back-up of the information on that system, and the parties may prefer for this to be made explicit as part of the deletion obligation.

Disputes between supplier and customer almost inevitably arise during systems integration projects, most commonly from failures to communicate. On the supplier's side, there is a natural reluctance to admit that things are not going to plan, so the customer may only become aware that there is a problem when it has become so great as to threaten the whole project. On the customer's side, there is often a failure to communicate its requirements properly at an early stage, and a sense of failed expectations when the system does not meet these uncommunicated requirements.
See Practice note, Issues in IT contracts litigation.

Standard boilerplate clauses often simply give exclusive jurisdiction to the courts of the country in which the party drafting the contract resides. Litigation should be the last resort for disputes arising during the implementation of a systems integration project as it is expensive, slow and adversarial. However, to leave the decision about the alternative method of resolving a dispute until the dispute has actually arisen is also a recipe for disaster as there may already be hurt feelings and a lack of trust at that point. It is, therefore, important that a carefully considered method of dealing with disputes is agreed and written into the contract before the project begins.

The usual method of approaching this is to provide for an escalation of methods, at first internal and then involving an outside party. The standard document provides for such an escalation, with the outside party acting as a mediator. There are a number of types of dispute resolution involving third parties.
Any dispute which may arise between the parties concerning this agreement shall be determined as provided in this clause 45.
For the purpose of this clause 45, a dispute shall be deemed to have arisen when one party serves on the other a notice in writing stating the nature of the dispute.

These clauses set out the escalation procedure for dealing with disputes. First, there must be a formal step for starting the procedure (clause 45.2). Initially, the supplier's project manager and the customer's project director should try to resolve the dispute if possible (clause 45.4(a)). Many disputes can be nipped in the bud by good collaboration between these individuals so it is important that they have a good working relationship.

If these two individuals cannot resolve the dispute, it should then go to senior management (clause 45.4(b)). However, this will only be successful if the senior managers have responsibility for, and ownership of, the project in their respective organisations and sufficient authority to take potentially risky decisions that are binding on their company. It is a good idea to provide for maximum time periods for both levels of discussion, as delay in resolving the dispute could itself endanger the project. On the other hand, the best settlement is always one reached by the parties themselves, so sufficient time should be allowed for this to happen.

In the standard document, failure by the parties to resolve the dispute themselves then leads to mediation (clause 45.4(c)). There are also other methods of alternative dispute resolution that could be used (see Standard clause, Multi-tiered dispute resolution procedure).

As a final resort, there needs to be a binding third-party adjudication, either by way of arbitration or court proceedings (clause 45.5). Arbitration and litigation both have their advantages and disadvantages, but neither is quick or cheap. You may wish to consider the arbitration services offered by the London Court of International Arbitration and the International Chamber of Commerce. The standard document attempts to assign the more suitable form to each of the potential kinds of technical and legal disputes, but there can even be disputes over the nature of the dispute. If arbitration is to be used, there should be provision in the agreement (Annex 9) for at least the basic rules and procedure to be followed as, unlike in litigation, there is no single, legally binding standard set of rules. Again, leaving these to be decided only after a dispute has arisen could lead to stalemate and the collapse of the project.

Arbitration is an option particularly where one or more of the parties are established outside the UK. Briefly, the advantages of arbitration are that the parties can set their own procedure (including joinder of parties such as subcontractors), arbitration may be better suited to an international dispute and the proceedings can remain confidential. For more information on the advantages of arbitration and on choosing appropriate arbitration rules, see Practice notes, Why parties arbitrate: advantages and disadvantages and Major international commercial arbitration rules: comparison and key features.

Unless this agreement has already been terminated by the date of the notice of dispute, the Supplier shall, in every case, continue with the Work with all due diligence regardless of the nature of the dispute and the Customer shall continue to make payments in accordance with Schedule 4.

Unless the situation is so serious that the agreement is terminated, both parties have an interest in continuing performance during the period the dispute is being dealt with. The customer should be required to make payments to the supplier pending resolution of the dispute. As a fall-back position, the customer should only have the right to withhold payments relating to matters in dispute, and the supplier needs to be certain that, once the dispute is resolved, it promptly receives any money that is found to be due. One solution is for the customer to pay the disputed sums into an escrow account. This is particularly important where the supplier has doubts about the ability or willingness of the customer to make the payments, and it prevents such a customer from raising artificial disputes in order to delay making payments.
For information on multi-tiered dispute resolution procedure clauses, see the integrated drafting notes to Standard clause, Multi-tiered dispute resolution procedure.
After service of the notice of dispute, the following procedure shall be followed by the parties (all periods specified in this clause 45.4 shall be extendable by mutual agreement):

if the Project Manager and the Customer Representative are unable to reach a settlement within [seven] days from the date of service of the notice, the [managing directors] of each of the parties shall meet within the following [seven] days to attempt to settle the dispute; and

if no settlement results from the meeting specified in clause 45.4(b) for the following [28] days the parties shall attempt to settle the dispute by mediation by an independent mediator, with costs to be shared equally between the parties.
If no settlement is reached under clause 45.4:

if the dispute is of a technical nature concerning the interpretation of the Business Requirements Specification or Technical Specification or any similar or related matter, then such dispute shall be referred for arbitration, to be carried out in accordance with the arbitration procedure set out in Annex I. The arbitrator's decision shall (in the absence of clerical or manifest error) be final and binding on the parties and their fees for so acting shall be borne by the parties in equal shares unless they determine that the conduct of either party is such that such party should bear all of such fees;

in the case of a dispute over purely legal issues, or where disposition of the legal issues would dispose of all other issues in dispute, the matter shall be brought before the English High Court in the most expeditious manner possible, and the parties agree to co-operate in the speedy conduct of such legal proceedings; and
in any other case, the dispute shall be determined by the English High Court and the parties submit to the exclusive jurisdiction of such court for such purposes.
For information on governing law clauses, see the integrated drafting notes to Standard clause, Governing law and Practice note, Governing law and jurisdiction clauses.

This agreement and any dispute or claim arising out of or in connection with it or its subject matter or formation (including non-contractual disputes or claims) shall be governed by and interpreted in accordance with the law of England and Wales.

The supplier should normally want to have the law of the jurisdiction where it is based as the governing law of the contract. However, customers who are government bodies or publicly owned are often required by law to contract under the law of their own jurisdictions, and very large customers usually want to specify the law of the jurisdiction where they are based. Negotiations on this issue may require the assistance of suitably qualified lawyers from the jurisdiction in question.

Any exclusive jurisdiction chosen in this clause could be different from the jurisdiction of the governing law, but this would increase the cost of litigation as the trial court would have to hear evidence on the relevant provisions of the chosen governing law. If provisions for alternative dispute resolution procedures are to be included in any of the sections, this should be referred to here.
See Practice note, Supply contracts: overview: Choice of law and jurisdiction for a consideration of choice of law and jurisdiction provisions.

The maintenance and support agreement may well contain service levels and service credits.

Typically, descriptions of service levels will specify content, volume of services and performance levels such as availability, response times and details about help desks. Service levels should be described in as much detail as possible. These details will depend upon the nature of the services being provided. In any event, the service levels should make clear the period over which they are to be measured, for example, weekly, monthly or annually. The customer will generally produce the first draft, but legal review and drafting is essential.

Performance will need to be monitored and reports prepared. Issues include who will measure the performance, what exactly will be measured, how often the measurement will take place and the reporting arrangements. These details will need to be consistent with the record-keeping obligations and access and inspection arrangements set out in clause 15.8 of the main agreement.
The consequences of service level failures will also need to be specified. Apart from the service credit regime, these may include damages and termination rights and practical remedies.

Service credits are a pre-determined payment and, accordingly, it is important to fix the amounts of the credits at an appropriate level to help ensure their enforceability, and to have a liquidated damages clause. In some cases, the supplier should request the inclusion of service debits as well as credits, to reflect performance which is greater than the relevant service levels.
Service credits need not be attached to all service levels. They might only apply to those which would have a business impact, if not met.

Systems integration agreements typically have several schedules, which will contain details of matters and items to be provided under the agreement. The contract is more manageable if these details are in separate schedules at the end of the agreement rather than being set out in the body of the agreement, but the agreement must make it clear that these are contractual terms and conditions. It should also provide for possible conflicts between these documents (see Drafting note, Structure and content of agreement).

Where there are related agreements, for example, the software licence and maintenance agreement, they should be annexed to the main agreement. Annexation means that the agreements will be interpreted as related agreements. It also has the practical benefit of keeping all the agreements readily to hand in one place. The customer may assert that it is relying on representations made by the supplier in the response to the invitation to tender, in which case it will want to have these documents annexed to the main agreement. The supplier should strongly resist this, and may offer instead to incorporate in the agreement those specific representations the customer wants to rely on (see Drafting note, Structure and content of agreement and Drafting note, Entire agreement).
Although witnessing is not essential for the proper execution of agreements, it is good practice, particularly in the case of material transactions. Different rules apply to deeds.

The authority may be given by, for example, board resolution or power of attorney, however it will be necessary to check that the company may validly delegate its powers in this way and that the authority was duly given. In the case of foreign companies, this will require an opinion to be obtained from lawyers in the relevant jurisdiction.

The implementation plan is almost certain to be amended during the project (see Practice note, Main issues in systems integration contracts: Timetables). Both parties should set up a procedure to ensure that any agreed variation to the plan is recorded by attaching an amended project plan schedule, so that the agreement is kept up to date (see Drafting note, Implementation Plan and extension of time).

This annex must contain details of the tests to be carried out and the criteria that must be met in order for the tests to be successful. Ideally, the annex will be finalised before the systems integration project begins. However, in reality it is very rare for it to be completed before work begins for any but the simplest systems. This is because with most systems there has to be a preliminary period while the design is refined in the light of detailed discussions between the customer and supplier. Both tests and performance criteria will need to be amended to match the final design. If an acceptance testing procedure is not agreed by the time the systems integration agreement is signed, the agreement will need to have provisions dealing with how a procedure is to be agreed.
